【8】History of Present Illness:
___ year old woman with history of CKD on HD with multiple 
medical problems who presents after ___ discharge for one day 
with same symptoms of epigastric pain that radiates to the back. 
She had multiple admission in the last several months for the 
same complaint. States that she has 'chronic pancreatitis' that 
causes this pain about once a month. She was having epigastric 
pain that started after HD on day of admission and she had a 
"few" episodes of bilious vomiting. She attempted to take oral 
anti-emetic, but was unable to do so. She notes that this is the 
same symptoms as before. Pain is not associated with eating, is 
spontaneous in onset, but will often be related to HD. The only 
medication that makes her pain better is dilaudid. She denies 
any  
changes in her bowel movements, and denies any melena or blood 
in her stool. No hematemesis noted. She denies having any other 
complaints, feeling very tired and sleepy since she did not 
sleep well the night before.  
Of note, pt was just admitted on ___ for same complaint 
of epigastric pain. There was discussion about obtaining abd CTA 
given concern for mesenteric ischemia since her abdominal pain 
frequently starts at HD and her history of known atheroscloersis 
elsewhere. However, she had very difficulty IV access and the 
decision was made to do this as an outpatient. She will of She 
was sent home with no changes in her medications. During her 
prior admission, she is often made NPO and requires frenquent 
doses of IV dilaudid, even when she is asleeping and appears 
comfortable as per prior notes. Her pain usually improves 
spontaneously by 3 or ___ day and she goes home on Percocet. 
Patient on narcotic contract. She had extensive work-up during 
her prior admission which include EUS ___ showed some changes 
consistent with chronic pancreatitis but not enough to declare a 
diagnosis. Multiple endoscopies have shown only mild gastritis 
and duodenitis. Different imaging studies have shown 
unremarkable  
pancreas. Lead and porphyria were also negative.  
.  
.  
In the ED, initial vital signs were 98.5 87 198/88 12 97% RA  
Patient was given 1mg IV dilaudid x3 for pain. Labs were notable 
for creatine of 3.3 (pt had HD today),Lactate:0.9, AST: 20, ALT: 
12 AP: 126 Tbili: 0.1 Alb: 3.9, Serum ASA, EtOH, Acetmnphn, 
Benzo, Barb, Tricyc Negative.  
.  
On the floor, Patient was somnolent, but arousable- her vitals 
were 98.1, 151/56, 92, 16, 100% on 2L NC. She c/o mild pain, but 
overall feeling better. As per nursing she had one episode of 
100cc of billius emesis.

CTA ABD-PELVIS With and without contrast:
IMPRESSION: 
1. There is no evidence for mesenteric ischemia. 
2. Enlarging complex left groin pseudoaneurysm. Assessment by 
vascular 
surgery is suggested on an emergent basis. 
3. Stable bilateral renal cysts with an atrophic left kidney. 
Given the 
complex nature of the upper pole right renal cyst, this should 
be followed with ultrasound. 
4. Stable thrombosis of the right aortobifemoral bypass graft 
with patency of the left aortobifemoral bypass graft and 
crossover graft. 

【17】CTA lower extremity:
IMPRESSION:
1. Left groin pseudoaneurysm measuring approximately 6.2 x 4.2 
cm,
essentially stable from the most recent examination, however, 
enlarged from
___. This appears to originate in a retrograde manner 
from the
common femoral artery, just above the bifurcation.
2. Status post aortobifemoral and femoral-femoral bypass grafts. 
At the
junction of the two grafts, there are two smaller 
pseudoaneurysms measuring up to 1.4 cm that are also stable in 
size and appearance.
3. Significant atherosclerotic disease of the bilateral lower 
extremities
with multilevel stenoses, ranging from mild to severe. In the 
distal calf,
the left anterior tibial and peroneal arteries are diminutive. 
The left
posterior tibial artery provides dominant flow into the arch.
4. Stable thrombosis of the right limb of the aortobifemoral 
bypass graft.
5. Unchanged appearance of the kidneys containing multiple 
cysts. The left
kidney is atrophic.

【19】Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old with history of chronic pancreatitis, ESRD on HD 
TThSat, CAD s/p stenting, PVD s/p grafts, and diabetes admitted 
with epigastric abdominal pain after HD on day of admission with 
nausea and vomiting. Her symptoms gradually improved and started 
to tolerate oral intake with transition of medications to oral 
regimen. Constipation seemed to be a likely cause of her 
symptoms which resolved once constipation resolved. CTA 
abdomen-pelvis didn't show mesenteric ischemia.  showed increase 
in size of left common femoral artery pseudoaneurysm which was 
evaluated by vascular surgery. CTA lower extremity was done per 
vascular surgery recommendations for further outpatient 
management to be preceeded by a cardiology clinic visit for 
___ evaluation. She is discharged home in stable 
condition. 

【20】#Abdominal pain: Likely due to constipation.  Patient has had 
extensive work-up for abdominal pain in the past, including CT 
abd, EGDs, Colonoscopy, EGD/EUS showing slightly atropic 
pancreas which did not meet criteria for chronic pancreatitis. 
CTA abdomen was negative for mesenteric ischemia. Diet was 
gradually advanced as tolerated along with transitioning her 
anti-nausea and pain medications from IV to PO. She was able to 
tolerate food without nausea and her pain was well controlled. 
We continued PPI and ranitidine. She was instructed to take 
senna and colace standing doses and to hold if develops > 2 
loose stools per day. She was also instructed to take miralax 
once daily if constipated. 

【21】#Left groin pseudoaneursym: Evaluated by vascular surgery.  
Would prefer outpatient management by Dr. ___ who is closely 
monitoring her but preferred to have CTA of lower extremity 
prior to discharge which was done after ___ guided PICC line was 
placed for the imaging study (PICC line was removed prior to 
discharge). She will be evaluated by vascular surgery as 
outpatient which will be preceeded by cardiology clinic visit 
for ___ evaluation.  

【22】#Hypertension: She underwent dialysis per schedule. Her home 
medications metoprolol and amlodipine were continued. Her SBP 
was ranging 120-160's during her stay. Would recommend 
uptitrating amlodipine to 10 mg daily. 

【23】#ESRD on HD: We continued HD ___. We continued home 
cinacalcet, calcitriol, sevelamer.

tiotroprium per home regimen.  

【25】#Psych: history of schizoaffective disorder. We continued home 
citalopram and amitrityline.

【36】Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___,

【37】It was a great pleasure taking care of you as your doctor. As 
you know you were re-admitted to ___ because of worsening 
nausea and abdominal pain. During your stay we provided you IV 
anti nausea and IV pain killers with gradual improvement in your 
oral intake and symptoms. We gave you medications to help you 
move your bowels and your pain improved. Please taking standing 
daily doses of colace and senna as instructed to ensure good 
bowel movements. Please take the miralax daily as needed if you 
don't get a bowel movement in 2 days time of using standing 
doses of senna and colace.  

【38】We did a CT scan of your belly which showed increase in the size 
of the arterial dilatation in your left groin (common femoral 
artery). Vascular surgery was consulted who recommended imaging 
your left lower extremity. We had an IV access difficulty which 
required a PICC line to be placed by interventional radiology 
doctors. ___ imaging of your lower extremity will be reviewed 
with you when you see the vascular surgeon as an outpatient. It 
was recommended to have a surgical correction of this soon. You 
will need to be evaluated by heart doctors as outpatient as 
___ evaluation.
We did not make changes in your home medications except for the 
bowel regimen highlighted above, please continue taking your 
home medications the way you were taking at home prior to 
admission. 
.
Please follow with the appointments as illustrated below.

Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

【24】back.

with the surgeon.

medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
Incision Care:
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
Monitoring Ostomy output/Prevention of Dehydration:
-Keep well hydrated.
-Replace fluid loss from ostomy daily.
-Avoid only drinking plain water. Include Gatorade and/or other 
vitamin drinks to replace fluid.
-Try to maintain ostomy output between 1000mL to 1500mL per day.

chronic inflammatory/infectious process, a calcified soft tissue 
neoplasm such as a giant-cell tumor of the tendon sheath, 
tenosynovial osteochondromatosis, or deposition of calcified 
material (gout, CPPD, dermatomyositis).  Correlation with exam 
and clinical factors is recommended and if necessary

【13】Brief Hospital Course:
The patient with history of acute cholecystitis and PTC drain 
placement was admitted to the General Surgical Service for 
elective open cholecystectomy. On ___, the patient 
underwent open cholecystectomy, which went well without 
complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for 
details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the 
patient arrived on the floor NPO, on IV fluids, with a foley 
catheter, and Dilaudid PCA for pain control.  The patient was 
hemodynamically stable.
Neuro: The patient received Dilaudid PCA with good effect and 
adequate pain control.  When tolerating oral intake, the patient 
was transitioned to oral pain medications. Patient has a history 
of chronic back pain and he takes Oxycodone PO in home. While 
restarted Oxycodone patient complained about inadequate pain 
control and was switched to PO Dilaudid with good effect.
CV: Patient has a history of A-Fib, he is on Coumadin. Coumadin 
was held prior surgery. In hospital patient had several episodes 
of sinus tachycardia and his HR was monitored with telemetry 
unit. Prior discharge patient was started on his regular 
Coumadin dose. Patient instructed to continue follow up with PCP 
and check his INR on the regular bases. 
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirrometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.
GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV 
fluids. Diet was advanced when appropriate, which was well 
tolerated.  Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, 
and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary.  Electrolytes were 
routinely followed, and repleted when necessary.
ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were 
closely watched for signs of infection. Wound was monitored 
routinely, no s/s of infection were noticed.
Endocrine: Patient has history of IDDM, after surgery patient 
was started on sliding scale. On POD # 2, patient's preprandial 
___ was 450. ___ was called for consult, patient was restarted 
on home regiment. ___ downward to 130-200s and continued to 
stabilize. 
Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined 
routinely; no transfusions were required.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diabetic diet, ambulating with walker, voiding without 
assistance, and pain was well controlled.  The patient received 
discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding 
verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

【27】Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___. You were admitted to the hospital after a 
peripheral angiogram. To do the test, a small puncture was made 
in one of your arteries. The puncture site heals on its own: 
there are no stitches to remove. You tolerated the procedure 
well and are now ready to be discharged from the hospital. 
Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a speedy and 
uneventful recovery.

【28】Puncture Site Care
For one week:
Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot 
tub.
Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around 
the puncture site. 
Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. 
Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the 
puncture site. 

【29】You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the 
procedure.  You may leave the bandage off. 
You may have a small bruise around the puncture site.  This is 
normal and will go away one-two weeks. 

【30】Activity 
For the first 48 hours: 
Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure
For the first week:
Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 
pounds
Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold 
your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles.   Take care not 
to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, 
or moving your bowels.
After one week:
You may go back to all your regular activities, including 
sexual activity.  We suggest you begin your exercise program at 
half of your usual routine for the first few days.   You may 
then gradually work back to your full routine.
Medications:
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

【31】For  Problems or Questions:
Call ___ in an emergency such as:
Sudden, brisk bleeding or swelling at the groin puncture site 
that does not stop after applying pressure for ___ minutes
Bleeding that is associated with nausea, weakness, or 
fainting.
Call the vascular surgery office (___) right away if 
you have any of the following. (Please note that someone is 
available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week)
Swelling, bleeding, drainage, or discomfort at the puncture 
site that is new or increasing since discharge from the hospital
Any change in sensation or temperature in your legs
Fever of 101 or greater
Any questions or concerns about recovery from your angiogram

【31】# Newly diagnosed heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
As above, hypoxia, dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, ___ edema, 
elevated proBNP and a CXR with pulmonary edema and bilateral 
pleural effusions suggested new HF exacerbation. Troponins were 
mildly elevated and downtrended (0.15 to 0.11) and ECG was

active ischemia. TTE ___ demonstrated RV dilation without 
segmental wall motion abnormalities and LVEF >55%. Thus, a new 
diagnosis of HFpEF was made. She was diuresed aggressively on a 
Lasix drip for a total of negative >60 liters with significant 
improvement in her respiratory status. She underwent a right 
heart cath as below which showed pulmonary hypertension, and is 
likely the major contributor to her heart failure. At discharge, 
her diuretic regimen was torsemide 100 mg BID, and weight was 
167.7 kg.

【49】Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___,

【50】You were admitted to ___ for difficulty breathing in the 
setting of fluid overload. While here, you underwent an 
ultrasound of your heart, which showed dilation in the setting 
of excess fluid, as well as intact squeeze (a condition called 
heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, or HFpEF). We 
gave you IV medications in order to take fluid off, and as fluid 
was removed, your breathing improved. When you left the 
hospital, a total of 136 pounds of fluid were removed. Your "dry 
weight" was 369.7 lbs. You were discharged home with a 
medication called torsemide at a dose of 100 milligrams two 
times a day. This medication will help you keep fluid off. 
Because of low potassium caused by this drug, we started you on 
a drug called spironolactone to keep your potassium up and you 
will need to take oral potassium as well. Please weigh yourself 
at home every day, and if your weight increases by more than 2 
lbs in a day or by more than 5 lbs in a week, please call your 
doctor.

【51】You also had an ultrasound of your legs, which showed a possible 
blood clot. In addition, you were noted on the heart monitor to 
have an abnormal fast heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation. 
For the blood clot and for the abnormal heart rhythm, you were 
started on blood thinner medications (initially heparin through 
an IV, and later an oral medication called warfarin). In 
addition, in order to prevent your heart from beating too fast, 
you were started on a medication to slow the heart rate called 
metoprolol. Finally, given the blood clot we saw, it shall be 
important for you to follow-up with your primary care physician 
for blood tests for a condition called hypercoagulability, which 
is the tendency to form blood clots.

【52】During routine blood tests, you also tested positive for type 2, 
or adult-onset, diabetes (more specifically, your HbA1c test was 
6.5 %, and 6.5 % is the cut-off for being positive for diabetes, 
with higher numbers indicating higher average blood sugars). In 
addition, you were started on a medication called atorvastatin, 
which prevents heart disease and lowers cholesterol. You might 
also consider starting a medication called metformin for the 
diabetes, and your PCP can decide whether to do this. In 
addition, we discussed how weight loss and exercise (even 
exercise in the absence of weight loss) will be key to 
controlling your blood sugars and diabetes in the future. 

【53】Throughout your admission, you were noted to have low oxygen 
levels. These oxygen levels improved with a breathing machine 
and mask called BiPAP. We suspect that you may have a condition 
called obstructive sleep apnea as well as "obesity 
hypoventilation syndrome", which causes your lungs to not fill 
adequately. You underwent a "right heart catheterization" to 
measure pressures in your lungs, and we found that you have high 
lung pressures called "pulmonary hypertension". Because of this, 
you will need to wear your oxygen every day and your CPAP every 
night to help you reduce your lung pressures. You will need to 
see a pulmonologist (lung doctor) as an outpatient when you 
leave.

【54】You expressed interest in Bariatric Surgery during this 
admission, which is a type of surgery that can help patients 
lose weight. Diabetes, heart disease, sleep apnea and overall 
general health can all be improved with weight loss. Please talk 
to your PCP to receive ___ referral to Bariatric Surgery. 

【55】It was a pleasure taking care of you,
- Your ___ Team

【20】Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o M w/hx EtOH abuse found down with altered mental status, 
rhabdomyolysis and head CT showing right frontal brain lesion. 
Eventually, he was made full comfort focused care with a 
morphine gtt and died on ___ at 1:40 ___.

【21】# Frontal brain mass: Patient has edematous right frontal brain 
lesion of unclear etiology but possibly an ICH within a tumor. 
Likely contributing to patient's AMS.  He is now s/p dilantin 
load and steroids to control edema. Neuro-surgery and neurology 
were consulted.  On exam mild L>R anisocoria and perhaps mild R 
hemiparesis concerning for mass effect on from right uncus on 
cerebral peduncle and CN III.  He was continued on seizure 
prophylaxis with levetiracetam 1g IV BID and treated with high 
dose steroids.

【22】# Goals of care: In discussion with his family, they decided not 
to pursue aggressive treatment and did not elect for repeat 
brain MRI since it is very likely that he had a glioblastoma and 
they would not like to attempt aggressive treatment. Ongoing 
goals of care discussions were held, and eventually patient was 
made full comfort focused care, withdrawing all medications 
except those to that goal. He was managed with morphine IV and 
lorazepam for comfort and died from likely uncal herniation.

【23】Issues managed initially in ICU prior to transition to comfort 
focus on general floor:
# EtOH Withdrawal: In the MICU he was tremulous and altered 
although hemodynamically stable. If in withdrawal would also 
expect consistent autonomic instability and agitation as opposed 
to his current somulence and hemodynamics. Given time frame of 
his last drink, monitored closely for signs of DTs or seizure 
activity and non were observed. For his tremulousness and 
occasional tachycardia and hypertension he was treated with 
valium on a CIWA. ___ required 2.5mg valium in afternoon. ___ no 
longer scoring and CIWA dc'd.  Social work was consulted, and he 
was treated on thiamine, folate and multivitamin. These were 
stopped on transition to comfort focused care as above.

【24】#Anemia. ___ had hematocrit drop along with proportionate drop 
in WBC and plt count after massive fluid resuscitation (+8L). 
Likely dilutional, with underlying anemia perhaps from EtOh 
abuse.  Nutritional supplementation continued and continued to 
monitor HCT.  Labs were stopped on transition to ___ focused 
care as above.

【25】# Rhabdomyolysis: Found to have mild rhabdomyolysis with CK 2706 
which is likely due to patient being found down for unknown 
period of time. While his U/A did not have RBCs, there was 
likely a myoglobin component as well given his elevated CK. His 
creatinine was normal suggesting good renal function currently. 
CK trending down ___. He was treated with IVF, stopped on 
transition to ___ focused care as above.

【26】# Altered mental status: Patient is altered although unclear 
what his baseline usually is. This is likely multifactorial from 
the ___ w/associated edema, alcohol withdrawal, 
dehydration, possible hepatic encephalopathy, and sedation 
medications for withdrawal symptoms. No infectious etiology 
currently. U/A, CXR, and imaging unremarkable for infectious 
process. His mental status continued to decompensate, likely 
from uncal herniation and tumor mass effect. He was transitioned 
to ___ care as above.

【27】# Skin ulcerations/breakdown: Appears to be dependent and likely 
related to being down for unknown length of time. Imaging does 
not show fracture or dislocation. Unable to obtain a complete 
exam given patient's mental status but there is some concern for 
a possible nerve palsy of the right arm given his exam findings. 
Will need to follow closely when patient less altered.  Hand 
surgery consulted for to evaluate for compartment syndrome; no 
surgical intervention indicated. 

【28】# Hypovolemia: Based on the history, patient was likely 
hypovolemic on initial presentation particularly with an 
elevated lactate of 2.4 without another clear source. He 
currently appears euvolemic clinically after receiving 4L fluids 
prior to getting to the MICU and continues to make to UOP. 
However, bedside ultrasound showed collapsable IVC and IJs and 
he received additional IVF. Lactate normalized with fluids. 

【29】# Liver disease/Cirrhosis: Patient has know EtOH cirrhosis and 
varices (s/p banding) with baseline mild transaminitis. His 
coags were at baseline which is reassuring for maintained liver 
synthetic function. CT did not show evidence of cholecystitis or 
ductal dilation and AP is normal. His T bili was slightly 
increased from his baseline of 1.2 which may be related to 
breakdown given his time down.

【13】Brief Hospital Course:
Pt admitted on conditional voluntary basis.  Was found to be 
appropriate for 15 minute checks and remained in good behavioral 
control throughout his hospital stay.  
He requested ETOH detox and ultimate disposition to a 28 day 
program for help with sobriety maintenance and was started on an 
ETOH detox protocol with lorazepam (vs. valium due to elevated 
LFTS and +Hep C).  His suboxone maintenance was continued.  On 
the second day of hospitalization the pt stated he no longer 
desired to be tapered off clonazepam and would thus forfeit a 28 
day program for an IOP.  By time of discharge he was 
transitioned to standing clonazepam with a goal of eventual 
discontinuation with the help of outpt treaters.  Given his 
active substance use, pt also requested to discontinue 
citalopram, as he was unsure if it offered any benefit.
He participated in group therapy, but was often verbally 
inappropriate and irritable.
By the the third day of hospitalization he was stating he no 
longer felt hopeless and that his SI was often fleeting and in 
the context of increased substance use.   He described himself 
as a "generally fun loving ___ who enjoys life"  He worked with 
the treatment team to decide an appropriate discharge date.  He 
agreed to an IOP but declined help with setting up appts with 
PCP or ___ treaters.  When team attempted to make follow up 
appts with his outpt psych treater at ___, we were informed that 
due to pts noncompliance with appts, the only way he could be 
seen there again was for him to show up during walk-in hours.  
This was communicated to the patient and he voiced 
understanding.

【24】Discharge Instructions:
WHAT TO EXPECT:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

【25】MEDICATION:
Take aspirin and low dose rivaroxaban as instructed 
Follow your discharge medication instructions

【26】ACTIVITIES:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

【27】You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
You should gradually increase your activity
You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed

【28】CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
Redness that extends away from your incision
A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication

【29】 * Your injury caused 5 rib fractures which can cause severe

of the pain.

【30】* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.

【31】* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.

【32】* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.

【33】* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.

【34】* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.

【35】* Do NOT smoke

【36】* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin,

effects so make sure your doctor approves.

【21】Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Video-Assisted L 
Thorascopic chest washout and decortication for the infection 
around your lung. You have recovered from this procedure well 
and you are now ready to return home. You are breathing well, 
have tolerated a regular diet, are passing gas and your pain is 
controlled with pain medications by mouth. You may return home 
to finish your recovery.  
 Please monitor your breathing function. Continue to use your 
incentive spirometer 10 times an hour while awake. Check your 
incisions daily and report any increased redness or drainage. 
Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining. Your chest 
tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours. If it starts to drain, 
cover it with a clean dry dressing and change it as needed to 
keep site clean and dry. If you experience worsening shortness 
of breath, severe chest pain, please come to the emergency room 
for immediate evaluation.  
 You will be prescribed narcotic pain medication oxycodone. This 
medication should be taken when you have pain and as needed as 
written on the bottle. This is not a standing medication. You 
should continue to take Tylenol for pain around the clock and 
you can also take Advil. Please do not take more than 3000mg of 
Tylenol in 24 hours. Do not drink alcohol while taking narcotic 
pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive a car while 
taking narcotic pain medication. If you are taking narcotic pain 
medications there is a risk that you will have some 
constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace or Miralax, and if the symptoms do not improve 
call the office. If you have any of the following symptoms 
please call the office for advice or go to the emergency room if 
severe: increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal 
pain, nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, 
prolonged loose stool, or extended constipation. If your doctor 
allows you may also take Ibuprofen to help relieve the pain. 
Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions  
 You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on the side of 
your chest which are closed with internal sutures and a skin 
glue called Dermabond. These are healing well, however it is 
important that you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of 
infection including: increasing redness of the incision lines, 
white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the 
incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or 
swelling of the area. Please call the office if you develop any 
of these symptoms or a fever. You may go to the emergency room 
if your symptoms are severe.  
 You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. 
The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with 
steri-strips (little white adhesive strips) instead of 
Dermabond, these will fall off over time, please do not remove 
them. Please no baths or swimming for 6 weeks after surgery 
unless told otherwise by your surgical team. Please no lotions 
or creams to incision site until at least your postop visit.  
 Please walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your 
activity as you can tolerate. No heavy lifting greater than 6 
lbs for until your first post-operative visit after surgery, 
unless otherwise instructed. Please no strenuous activity until 
this time unless instructed otherwise by Dr. ___.  
 Call Dr. ___ office at ___ or visit the emergency 
room if you experience any of the following:  
 -Temp > 101, chills, increased shortness of breath, chest pain 
or any other symptoms that concern you.  
 Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities.

【24】Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital and underwent 
adjustment stent graft in your aorta to strengthen the part of 
the artery that was weakened by an aneurysm.  To perform this 
procedure, small punctures were made in the artery of your right 
groin.  You tolerated the procedure well and are now ready to be 
discharged from the hospital.   Please follow the 
recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful 
recovery, in preparation for a second surgery needed to remove 
the residual aneurysmal sac and ligate your lumbar arteries. 

【25】Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Endovascular Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Repair Discharge 
Instructions

【26】PLEASE NOTE: After endovascular aortic repair (EVAR), it is very 
important to have regular appointments (every ___ months) for 
the rest of your life.  These appointments will include a CT 
(CAT) scan and/or ultrasound of your graft.  If you miss an 
appointment, please call to reschedule. 

【27】WHAT TO EXPECT:
Bruising, tenderness, and a sensation of fullness at the groin 
puncture sites (or incisions) is normal and will go away in 
one-two weeks

【28】CARE OF THE GROIN PUNCTURE SITES:
It is normal to have mild swelling, a small bruise, or small 
amounts of drainage at the groin puncture sites.  In two weeks, 
you may feel a small, painless, pea sized knot at the puncture 
sites.  This too is normal.  Male patients may notice swelling 
in the scrotum.  The swelling will get better over one-two 
weeks.
Look at the area daily to see if there are any changes.  Be 
sure to report signs of infection.  These include: increasing 
redness; worsening pain; new or increasing drainage, or drainage 
that is white, yellow, or green; or fever of 101.5 or more.  (If 
you have taken aspirin, Tylenol, or other fever reducing 
medicine, wait at least ___ hours after taking it before you 
check your temperature in order to get an accurate reading.)
FOR SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or 
incision)
If you have sudden, severe bleeding or swelling at either of 
the groin puncture sites: 
-Lie down, keep leg straight and apply (or have someone apply) 
firm pressure to area for ___ minutes with a gauze pad or 
clean cloth. 
-Once bleeding has stopped, call your surgeon to report what 
happened.   
-If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest 
Emergency Room. 
You may shower 48 hours after surgery.  Let the soapy water 
run over the puncture sites, then rinse and pat dry.  Do not rub 
these sites and do not apply cream, lotion, ointment or powder. 
Wear loose-fitting pants and clothing as this will be less 
irritating to the groin puncture sites. 

【29】MEDICATIONS
Take aspirin daily.  Aspirin helps prevent blood clots that 
could form in your repaired artery. 
It is very important that you never stop taking aspirin or 
other blood thinning medicines-even for a short while- unless 
the surgeon who repaired your aneurysm tells you it is okay to 
stop.   Do not stop taking them, even if another doctor or nurse 
tells you to, without getting an okay from the surgeon who first 
prescribed them. 
You will be given prescriptions for any new medication started 
during your hospital stay.
Before you go home, your nurse ___ give you information about 
new medication and will review all the medications you should 
take at home.  Be sure to ask any questions you may have.  If 
something you normally take or may take is not on the list you 
receive from the nurse, please ask if it is okay to take it. 

【30】PAIN MANAGEMENT
Most patients do not have much pain following this procedure.  
 Your puncture sites may be a little sore.  This will improve 
daily. If it is getting worse, please let us know.
You will be given instructions about taking pain medicine if 
you need it.

【31】ACTIVITY
You must limit activity to protect the puncture sites in your 
groin.  For ONE WEEK:
-Do not drive
-Do not swim, take a tub bath or go in a Jacuzzi or hot tub
-Do not lift, push, pull or carry anything heavier than five 
pounds
-Do not do any exercise or activity that causes you to hold your 
breath or bear down with your abdominal muscles.
-Do not resume sexual activity
Discuss with your surgeon when you may return to other regular 
activities, including work.  If needed, we will give you a 
letter for your workplace. 
It is normal to feel weak and tired.  This can last six-eight 
weeks, but should get better day by day.   You may want to have 
help around the house during this time.
___ push yourself too hard during your recovery.  Rest when 
you feel tired.  Gradually return to normal activities over the 
next month.
We encourage you to walk regularly. Walking, especially 
outdoors in good weather is the best exercise for circulation.  
Walk short distances at first, even in the house, then do a 
little more each day.
It is okay to climb stairs.  You may need to climb them slowly 
and pause after every few steps. 

【32】DIET
It is normal to have a decreased appetite.  Your appetite will 
return over time.
Follow a well balance, heart-healthy diet, with moderate 
restriction of salt and fat. 
Eat small, frequent meals with nutritious food options (high 
fiber, lean meats, fruits, and vegetables) to maintain your 
strength and to help with wound healing.

【33】BOWEL AND BLADDER FUNCTION
You should be able to pass urine without difficulty.  Call you 
doctor if you have any problems urinating, such as burning, 
pain, bleeding, going too often, or having trouble urinating or 
starting the flow of urine.   Call if you have a decrease in the 
amount of urine. 
You may experience some constipation after surgery because of 
pain medicine and changes in activity.  Increasing fluids and 
fiber in your diet and staying active can help.  To relief 
constipation, you may talk a mild laxative.   Please take to 
your pharmacist for advice about what to take. 
SMOKING
If you smoke, it is very important that you STOP.   Research 
shows smoking makes vascular disease worse.  This could increase 
the chance of a blockage in your new graft.  Talk to your 
primary care physician about ways to quit smoking.

improvement in his language. At this time his wife noted that 
his personality was very different, more energetic and happy. He 
had an echocardiogram which showed no cardioembolic source. He 
was monitored on telemetry and remained in normal sinus rhythm. 
MRI showed posterior insula and inferior parietal lobes 
bilaterally, as well as medial temporal lobes. Given the initial 
reports or shaking the patient underwent EEG which showed no 
signs of seizure. When the patient was able to contribute to the 
history he reported that he had a baseline tremor that was 
likely the source of this report. Given the location of the 
stroke and the history of atrial fibrillation it is most likely 
that the stroke was due to embolus. The patient was therefore 
started on coumadin. He was seen by OT and speech and language 
and was discharged home with no services.

【15】Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing a total laparascopic hysterectomy converted to 
a total abdominal hysterectomy, and removal of a peritonea cyst.

【16】Her post-operative course was complicated by post-operative 
ileus and slow to return bowel function. Immediately post-op, 
her pain was controlled with IV pain medications. On 
post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her foley 
was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was advanced 
without difficulty and she was transitioned to oral pain meds.  
She passed minimal flatus and had no bowel movement by 
post-operative day 3.  She felt uncomfortable and her abdomen 
was moderately distended and tympanic on exam, so an abdominal 
x-ray was ordered that demonstrated a non-obstructive pattern of 
gas.  She received an aggressive bowel regimen and by 
post-operative day 5 was more comfortable, less distended, and 
having small bowel movements and flatus.  On post-operative day 
4, she developed lower extremity tenderness, worse on R side 
compared with L. Lower extremity dopplers were done ___ 
which showed no evidence of a DTV and her pain resolved 
spontneously and was attributed to MSK pain.

【17】By post-operative day 5, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

【37】Brief Hospital Course:
___ gentleman with a history of nonischemic 
cardiomyopathy, AICD, chronic atrial fibrillation and BOOP on 2L 
NC intermittently presenting with near-orthostatic syncope.

【38】# Persistent orthostasis:  Patient initially presented with 
orthostasis (up to 30 points systolic) largely as weakness in 
his legs but no symptoms of lightheadedness.  Likely had 
component of volume depletion and component of cardiogenic shock 
given CI of 1.2 from ___ cardiac cath.  Lactate initially 
elevated at 3.6, with ABG demonstrating acute respiratory 
alkalosis. We initially gave 1L NS, and the orthostasis 
persisted.  When the AM cortisol level returned lower than 
expected at 2.5, we gave a single dose of 100mg hydrocortisone, 
again with persistent orthostasis and no increase in heart rate 
with standing.  Endocrine was consulted and did not believe this 
was due to adrenal insufficiency. The EP service interrogated 
the AICD, which was pacing 27% of the time with a single lead in 
the right ventricle.  There were no events, however, which would 
explain the patient's orthostasis.  We continued to give back 
fluids, a total of 5L while holding lasix/ spironolactone and 
metoprolol.  Physical therapy worked with the patient and 
determined that he was safe for home with ___. ECHO from ___ 
did not have any evidence of valvular disease or LVOT 
obstruction to explain the patient's symptoms.  Additionally, 
there was no longitudinal shortening of the base of the heart 
and the E' waveform, both arguing against amyloidosis.  
Nonetheless, we sent off the a sample of the patient's lung 
tissue for ___ Red staining, which was pending at time of 
discharge. Given that patient remained orthostatic despite 
holding diuretics, moderate fluid repletion, and ruling out 
structural/ arrhythmogenic/ adrenal causes of the orthostasis, 
we decided to start a small dose of fludrocortisone to help 
increase intravascular volume, with the understanding that the 
serum sodium ___ rise and the patient was asked to drink free 
water.  He was also asked to monitor for signs of edema and 
contact his PCP as well as hold the fludrocortisone if that 
develops.  We also gave the patient information for follow up 
with neurology at time of discharge to investigate other 
etiologies of the orthostasis (i.e. autonomic dysfunction).

【39】# Question of adrenal insufficiency: Endocrine did not believe 
the patient has adrenal insufficiency.  When dose is decreased 
to 10 mg, the taper should be continued very slowly. Would also

【24】Discharge Instructions:
Mr ___,
You were admitted to ___ after a mechanical fall. You 
fractured your ___ ribs on the right side. Your respiratory 
status was monitored closely and your pain was managed. We had 
Physical Therapy work with you, and you were deemed safe to 
return home with home ___. Your INR was dangerously high when you 
came to the hospital so you were given vitamin K to reverse its 
effects. You can follow-up with your PCP and cardiologist to 
discuss the risks and benefits of restarting this medication.   

【25】* Your injury caused 3 rib fractures which can cause severe pain 
and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of 
the pain.

【26】* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.

【27】* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.

【28】* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.

【29】* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.

【30】* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.

【31】* Do NOT smoke

【32】* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.

【33】* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

【23】 Laparoscopic cholecystectomy:
 Ms. ___, it was a pleasure to have taken care of you at 
our service at the ___. You 
were admitted to the hospital with symptomatic gall stones and 
an incarcerated umbilical hernia. You were taken to the 
operating room and had your gallbladder removed laparoscopically 
and your umbilical hernia was also removed simultaneously. You 
tolerated the procedure well and are now being discharged home 
to continue your recovery with the following instructions.

【24】 Please follow up in the Surgery clinic at the appointment 
listed below.

【25】 ACTIVITY:

【26】 o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
 o You may climb stairs. 
 o You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
 o Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
 o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
 o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.

【27】 HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
 o You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
 o You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
 o You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.
 o You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
 o All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.

【28】 YOUR INCISION:
 o Tomorrow you may shower. Please keep the umbilical tension 
bandage (the brown bandage) on for ___ days. Do not remove 
steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are the thin paper strips that 
might be on your incision, but if they fall off before that 
that's okay.)
 o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
 o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
 o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
 o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
 o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
 o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.

【29】 YOUR BOWELS:
 o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
 o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 

【30】 PAIN MANAGEMENT:
 o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
 o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
 o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
 o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before 
your pain gets too severe.
 o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
 o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
 o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
 If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
 - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
 - pain that is getting worse over time
 - pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

【31】 MEDICATIONS:
 Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
 If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon

【21】Brief Hospital Course:

NEURO
Following arrival, the patient was observed to have persistent 
facial twitching thought to be consistent with seizure activity. 
 He was therefore given ativan 2 mg and a dilantin load.  A post 
load dilantin level (corrected for albumin) was found to be 
therapeutic (19.2).  The patient's outpatient lamictal regimen 
was also increased for improved seizure prophylaxis.  No further 
clinical seizure activity was evident.  A routine EEG was 
performed and demonstrated encephalopathy but no epileptiform 
activity.  An underlying trigger could not be readily 
identified.  Phenytoin level on day of discharge was 16.2.  The 
patient's lamotrigine should be increased to 150 mg daily in 1 
week after discharge, and continued at that dose thereafter.  
The phenytoin will be weaned.  It should be given at 300mg PO 
daily for 2 weeks, then 200mg PO daily for 1 week, then 100mg PO 
daily for 1 week, then stop.  He received his daily doses of 
lamotrigine and phenytoin on the day of discharge.
As the patient was found on the floor at ___, a CT of the 
cervical spine was performed; there was no evidence of fracture. 
 A non-contrast CT of the head revealed no contributory 
intracranial pathology.  He was seen by physical therapy and 
could walk with a walker (with assist).
RESP

GI

liquids on discharge, and was resumed on oral medications.

【21】Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo F with a history of HTN, hypothyroidism, DM2, anemia,

【22】The patient had 2 recent hospitalizations at ___ 
for abdominal pain. The second admission, from ___ she 
developed a profound pancreatitis with lipase up to 2665. She 
had a negative work-up at that time including MRCP and CT 
without findings of biliary obstructive disease. She improved 
with conservative therapy and was discharged home. She returns 
with recurrent abdominal pain and was found to have recurrent 
acute pancreatitis. 

【23】She was admitted to the medical floor, given IV fluids, bowel 
rest, anti-emetics and pain control. CT abdomen revealed 
findings of acute pancreatitis without obvious obstruction. 
Based upon the laboratory findings of a mild transaminitis and 
mild hyperbilirubinemia, she underwent ERCP with sphincterotomy. 
She did not have definitive findings on ERCP of obstruction. 
With IV fluids and bowel rest, her laboratory values and 
clinical status improved with resolution of the pancreatitis. 
She has a residual elevation in alkaline phosphatase which is 
long-standing. The patient will follow-up with her outpatient 
gastroenterologist. At the time of discharge, IgG subclass 
testing is pending as work-up for possible autoimmune 
pancreatitis. If these results suggest such a diagnosis, she may 
end up being started on steroids as an outpatient.

【24】The patient had a low grade transaminitis that improved with 
volume repletion and holding of her home statin. She does have 
persistent, downtrending alk phos elevation. She has a component 
of fatty liver disease based upon imaging reports. 

【25】The patient presented with hyponatremia. This resolved with 
overnight hydration and likely reflected volume depletion. This 
has been documented previously, including during her ___ 
___ and may also be related to antidepressant use.

【26】The patient has a history of numerous additional medical 
problems including anemia of chronic disease based upon lab 
testing during this hospitalization, asthma, depression, GERD, 
hypertension, hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. She was 
continued on her home medication regimen for these issues. In 
addition, she was placed on an insulin sliding scale for DM2.

may alternate these medications for pain control.  For pain 
control, try TYLENOL FIRST, then ibuprofen, and then take the 
narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief 
is needed.

【28】-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4.

【29】-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL

operate dangerous machinery

【33】-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation

stool-softener, NOT a laxative

【30】Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year old man with a history of atrial 
fibrillation on Coumadin (but noncompliant with medications and 
INR 1.2 on admission), hypertension, and hyperlipidemia who 
presented with left sided weakness and dysarthria. Physical exam 
on admission was significant for left neglect, apraxia, left 
facial droop, mild left hemiparesis, and pain limiting strength 
in the right leg. MRI/MRA Brain/Neck showed large infarction in 
the right middle cerebral artery territory with a small area of 
hemorrhagic transformation in the right putamen. There was 40 to 
50% short-segment stenosis at the right ICA origin and 50 to 60% 
short-segment stenosis at the left ICA origin. TTE showed LVEF 
45-50%, mild global hypokinesis, and moderate pulmonary 
hypertension.
His outpatient cardiologist, Dr. ___, reported that ___ 
days prior to admission he was faxed an EKG from the patient 
which showed atrial flutter with 2:1 conduction. The patient's 
admission EKG showed sinus rhythm with non-specific ST-T wave 
changes in leads I, aVL and V2-V6 and QT prolongation. It was 
thought that the patient had the stroke in the setting of 
converting from atrial fib/flutter to sinus rhythm in the 
setting of sub-therapeutic INR (1.2). 
Lipid panel showed: Tchol 199, LDL 135, HDL 45, ___ 97, and the 
patient was started on Atorvastatin 40 mg daily. It should be 
noted that the patient has a history of rash with Simvastatin 
use, so this should be monitored for as an outpatient. HgA1C 
5.6. Urine/serum tox negative. His Lisinopril was held to allow 
for autoregulation in the setting of acute stroke, and his SBP 
was 120-140 at the time of discharge. His Lisinopril can be 
added back in rehab if needed for hypetension. 
His CK was 863 on admission with CK-MB 14 and TropT 0.04. His CK 
peaked at 1018 but was trending down at the time of discharge. 
His elevated CK was thought to be due to myositis since the 
patient was found down. Less likely, he had demand ischemia. He 
was continued on Metoprolol 25 mg bid.
The patient was continued on Amiodarone 100 mg daily. His TSH 
was found to be up to 17 and Free T4 0.39. This was thought to 
be due to amiodarone use, and his Levoxyl was increased to 125 
mcg daily.
Routine CXR on admission showed increased elevation of the left 
hemidiaphragm which may be due to increased intraabdominal 
pressure. His PCP reported this was not previously known. This 
should be followed up as an outpatient.
The patient complained of right knee and left shoulder pain 
after being found down. X-rays of those regions showed a large 
knee effusion, but no evidence of fracture or dislocation.
His Hct was 47.2 on admission, but trended down likely due to 
initial hemoconcentration. His Hct was 36.9 at the time of 
discharge, and he was found to have macrocytosis. He had Vitamin 
B12 and folate levels pending at the time of discharge.

【28】Discharge Instructions:
Please call the transplant clinic  for fever > 101, chills, 
nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, inability to tolerate 
food, fluids or medications, yellowing of skin or eyes, 
increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, drainage or 
bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased urine output or dark, 
cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or ankles, weight gain of 3 
pounds in a day or any other concerning symptoms.

【29】You will have labwork drawn twice weekly **On the days you have 
your labs drawn, do not take your Tacrolimus until your labs are 
drawn. Bring your Tacrolimus with you so you may take your 
medication as soon as your labwork has been drawn.

【30】Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage 
changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or 
hospital visits.

【31】You may shower with soap and water, rinse, pat dry. Do not apply 
lotions or powder near the incision. You may leave the incision 
open to the air. The staples have been removed on ___

【32】Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat, 
and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go 
outdoors.

【33】Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your 
appetite will return with time. 

【34】Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without 
consultation with the transplant clinic. There are significant 
drug interactions with anti-rejection medications which must be 
considered in medication management following transplant

【35】Drain in collection near kidney
Drain and record the JP drain output  daily and as needed so 
that the drain is never more than ½ full. Call the transplant 
coordinator if the drain output increases by more than 100 cc 
from the previous day,  becomes bloody or develops a foul odor.

【36】Change the drain dressing once daily or after your shower. Do 
not allow the drain to hang freely at any time. Inspect the site 
for redness, drainage or bleeding. Make sure there is a stitch 
at the drain site.

Instructions after Surgery
It is normal to feel tired or washed out after surgery. Rest is 
important and will help you feel better. Walking is also 
important. It will help prevent problems and help you feel 
stronger and have more energy.  Just remember to pace yourself 
and rest when you feel tired.

【24】Follow these important instructions below: 

【25】What medications ___ I need to take?
-Take your pain medicine the way your doctor tells you to. 
___ not drink alcohol, drive, or use machinery while you are 
taking narcotic pain medicine.
As your pain lessens, decrease the amount of pain medicine you 
are taking.
-Narcotic pain medicine can cause constipation. To make it 
easier to have a bowel movement:
Drink extra water and other fluids like juice, tea, and broth.
Take a stool softener like docusate.  Docusate is also called 
Colace. You can buy it over the counter.
-Resume all of your home medications unless advised otherwise.

【26】What activities am I allowed at home?
-Walking is encouraged. 
-___ not ___ any strenuous exercise like aerobics, running or 
weight lifting until your surgeon says it is ok.
-___ not lift more than 10 pounds for ___ weeks. Ten pounds is as 
heavy as a gallon of milk. 

【27】How ___ I care for my incisions?
-It is ok to leave your incisions uncovered.  You may also cover 
them with dry gauze if your incisions are draining or to protect 
them from irritation.
-___ not shower or get wound wet for 48 hours after drain is 
removed. After this you may shower normally.  ___ not scrub your 
incision.  Gently wash with soapy water and pat wound dry 
afterwards.  Please ___ not immerse wound in bath, swimming, or 
sauna for ___ weeks or until wound completely healed/closed.

have fevers > ___ F, if your wound appears red, hot, painful or 
swollen, if your wound opens, or for anything else that is 
troubling you.

1. Native three vessel coronary artery disease with chronic 
total occlusions of the LAD and RCA and
chronic subtotal occlusion of the CX.
2. Patent LIMA-LAD with progression of downstream native LAD.
3. Patent SVG-OM/LPL.
4. Left common femoral calcific atherosclerosis.
5. Successful deployment of a drug-eluting stent in the native 
LAD via the LIMA in a fibrotic somewhat
resistant lesion.
Recommendations
1. Cycle CK-MB and troponin-T.
2. ASA 81 mg daily (do NOT load with 162 or 324 mg even if 
patient develops acute coronary syndrome as this may blunt the 
cardioprotective effects of ticagrelor by exceeding the FDA 
labeled maximal daily dose of ASA 100 mg daily).
3. Ticagrelor 90 mg BID for an additional year for post-MI 
secondary prevention with ACS indication of newly placed 
drug-eluting stent and for post-MI mortality benefit if no major 
issues with bleeding.
4. Reinforce secondary preventative measures against PAD, CAD 
and NSTEMI.
5. Suggest EP interrogation of pacemaker to see if patient is 
actually ventricular pacing with tracking of a rapid atrial rate 
rather than mode switching.
6. LFA sheath to be removed when ACT falls.

previously completed.

extremity, which was subsequently restored.  He also developed

beginning approximately 9 mm distal to the origin of the left 
subclavian artery immediately proximal to the origin of the left 
vertebral artery and did not extend into the left vertebral 
artery due to the presence of significant atherosclerotic 
calcification.  The flap extends into the left axillary artery 
and brachial artery to the bifurcation of the brachial artery.  
It does not appear to extend into the radial and ulnar arteries. 
.  ___ was consulted and he was provided a script for

【40】Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

【41】You were admitted to the hospital because you had a fracture of 
the bones of your left leg. You underwent a procedure called 
open reduction and fixation with orthopedic surgery. Because of 
concern that the bone was infected, you were started on an 
antibiotic called vancomycin and a PICC line was placed so you 
could continue this after you leave. You will need to continue 
this antibiotic for ___ weeks; the infectious disease doctors 
___ decide this when they follow up with you. You will also 
need to continue your minocycline. 
Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.

【42】INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

【43】ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Touch-down weight bearing left lower extremity

【44】MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

【45】WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet

【46】DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

# Atrial flutter/fib: Patient was diagnosed with AFib and

was not responsive to pharmacotherapy.  She had a TEE in the 
MICU, which was negative for thrombus, and then underwent 
cardioversion in the MICU.  After transfer to the floor, she 
converted back into AFib.  She continued to vacillate between 
AFib and NSR during her hospital stay.  She was admitted on 200 
mg Amiodarone daily.  She was placed on Amiodarone 200 mg BID, 
Verapamil 360 mg daily, and Digoxin 0.125 mg daily, yet she 
still converted back into AFib. She was thus tried on 40 mg 
short-acting Verapamil TID, but this also did not put her back 
into continuous NSR.  Her rate continued to remain in the 110s 
to 130s despite maximal medical management, yet the patient 
remained asymptomatic and was successfully ambulating in the 
halls.  She was discharged on 360 mg Verapamil daily, 200 mg 
Amiodarone BID, 0.125 mg Digoxin daily, and a follow-up 
appointment with Dr. ___ on ___. 
.  
# Constipation/Diarrhea: Patient had been constipated and was 
given a Fleets enema on ___. She then had an episode of 
diarrhea and developed a leukocytosis to 20.2. Patient was 
started on Flagyl 500 mg TID for suspected CDiff, though a 
subsequent culture was negative. She had another formed BM 24 
hours after ABX were started, and her leukocytosis improved. 
Patient had abdominal tenderness on physical exam, which 
resolved upon treatment with Flagyl.  Patient was discharged on 
Flagyl 400 mg TID for a total duration of 7 days treatment for 
suspected CDiff.  
.  
# COPD exacerbation: Patient was admitted with a COPD 
exacerbation.  She was placed on Levofloxacin, methylprednisone, 
and albuterol/Atrovent nebs on admission.  She completed a 
five-day course of Levofloxacin and was placed on a steroid 
taper.  Patient had repeated CXRs, which did not show any 
evidence of focal consolidation.  She received Xopenex and 
Ipratropium nebulizations every six hours, alternating, and she 
was placed on a Xopenex inhaler every two hours, as needed.  
Patient's shortness of breath improved throughout her hospital 
stay, and she was able to ambulate in the halls without 
shortness of breath.  
.  
# Type II Diabetes: Patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes, 
and she currently takes Metformin at home.  Patient's Metformin 
was held on admission to the hospital, and she was placed on a 
sliding scale insulin.  Her sugars remained well controlled 
during this hospital stay.

 Discharge Instructions:  
 INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:  
 - You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week.  
 - Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please 
follow your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.  
 ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:  
 - TDWB LLE  
 MEDICATIONS:  
1) Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is an 
over the counter medication.  
2) Add dilaudid 2 mg as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean 
off this medication in 1 week or sooner. This is an example on 
how to wean down:  
 Take 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,  
 then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,  
 then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,  
 then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days,  
 then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,  
 then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
 Then continue with Tylenol for pain.  
3) Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.  
4) Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone.  
5) Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue following 
the bowel regimen as stated on your medication prescription 
list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over the counter 
and may be obtained at any pharmacy.  
6) Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.  
7) Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.  
8) Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.  

【26】 ANTICOAGULATION:

 WOUND CARE:  
 - You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.  
 - Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.  
 - Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.  
 - If you have a splint in place, splint must be left on until 
follow up appointment unless otherwise instructed. Do NOT get 
splint wet.  
 DANGER SIGNS:  
 Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:  
 - Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications

desaturations.

continued on her home amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide for her 
history of hypertension.

voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Dear Ms. ___,

【22】You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with 
any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below.

【23】General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 
weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

【24】Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

【25】Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

【35】# Acute blood loss anemia on chronic anemia
# Thrombocytopenia
Presented with acute blood loss anemia due to spontaneous RP 
hematoma. Cause of bleed was unclear as the patient's 
coagulation tests were normal and his platelet count was normal 
upon admission. Discussed with hematology who did not think this 
presentation was consistent with an underlying coagulopathy 
given his relatively normal laboratory values. Uremic platelet 
dysfunction was considered, however patient has not been

Patient likely developed thrombocytopenia throughout his 
admission from a consumptive process. Continued home ferric 
citrate (auryxia).

control on oral analgesics. On exam, incision was clean, dry,

infection. The patient was given explicit instructions to

【13】Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o M with untreated HTN & bilateral lower extremity venous 
stasis, bilateral onychomycosis & R foot ulcer admitted with 
worsening foot pain.  
.  
1. RLE ulcer/MP joint bony destruction: Pt was seen in the ED on 
___ and was given a 10day course of Augmentin for RLE 
redness and swelling thought possibly consistent with cellulitis 
and was scheduled for oupt follow up with Podiatry for question 
of bony destruction seen at the ___ MP joint & concern for 
osteomyelitis. Pt returned to ___ before the podiatry appointment 
with c/o ongoing ___ pain and wanting better care for his feet. 
There was no evidence of cellulitis on admission to floor and pt 
was continued on Augmentin in house to complete the 10 day 
course.  Podiatry was consulted and felt that there was no 
evidence of ongoing cellulitis and no need for surgical 
intervention, they recommended outpatient follow up. There was 
no evidence of gout and no significant tenderness on exam. The 
RLE ulcer was superficial and recceived daily wound care in 
house.  The right foot film from the ED raised concern for 
underlying osteomyelitis.  However, the ESR of 0 and repeat of 3 
made osteo very unlikely.  Records were obtained from ___ 
___ that document 3 different admissions in ___ 
of the his year for the similar complaints of lower extremity 
pain.  Pt had a thorough work up for osteomyelitis including MRI 
and bone biopsy on ___.  The pathology report described 
reactive changes not consistent with infection.  The ___ records 
dcoument various outcomes with these admissions, including pt 
leaving AMA, refusing care & refusing SNF placement for ongoing 
antibiotic courses.  On the day of discharge from ___, pt 
expressed frustration about the lack on inhospital care for his 
feet. However, there were no ongoing medical issues requiring 
hospitalization.  The negative bone biopsy and ESR of zero made 
osteomyelitis very unlikely and Podiatry felt his ongoing 
onychomycosis & superficial skin ulcers were appropriate for 
outpatient follow up.  Pt was not requiring any medication for 
pain control and was scheduled to see podiatry four days after 
discharge .  He was given a prescription for topical 
clotrimazole BID and recommended to perform daily foot care to 
keep the wound clean.  
.  
2. Hypertension: Pt has untreated HTN and presented with 
significantly elevated BP in the 170/100 range. However, EKG did 
not show significant LVH. Pt was given education on the 
importance of blood pressure control and dietary modifications.  
Pt had a slight rise in creatinine noted after initiation of ACE 
from 1.1 to 1.3. However, urine lytes were consistent with a 
pre-renal etiology.  Pt was given IVF and creatinine came down 
to baseline of 1.1 prior to discharge. Pt acheived decent BP 
control on both lisinopril 10mg and Atenolol 50mg daily. Pt was 
discharged with prescriptions and was scheduled for a new 
primary care appointment on ___.  
.  
3. DM: Pt was noted to have 2 elevated fasting BS and Hgb A1c 
came back at 6.7 suggesting that pt has developped type II 
diabetes.  BS ranged in the 100-180s and pt was given education 
about the importance of weight loss and dietary changes to help 
prevent progression of DM.  Nutrition was consulted to provide 
additional diabetes education and pt was started on lisinopril 
for BP control and renal protection. Pt was scheduled for new 
PCP follow up and may need additional of an oral hypoglycemic in 
the future.  
4. Flank Rash: Pt reported a bilateral flank rash that began a 
few days prior to admission. The rash was over his bilateral 
flanks with macular erythema, it was not painful, but mildly 
pruritic. There were no vesicles to suggest Zoster and the 
distribution appeared to tracked along his belt line. Pt refused 
to remove the belt and felt this was necessary for supporting 
his back and felt there was no way the rash could be due to the 
belt. The rash was treated with sarna lotion daily and was 
stable in house.  It is possible that this was a contact 
dermatitis rash vs a drug reaction to Augmentin. Pt was 
encouraged to monitor this and discuss it with his PCP in follow 
up.

【30】# Hemoptysis:

concerning for malignancy, although she is not a smoker, no

given chronicity. No e/o pna or post-obstructive pna clinically 
or on CXR. DDx also includes chronic bronchitis but not a 
smoker. PE unlikely given absence of risk factors, hypoxia, or 
hemodynamic changes.  The patient was ruled out for active TB 
with three induced AFB smears >8 hours apart.    Interventional 
pulmonology evaluated patient during this hospitalization and 
follow-up was arranged at discharge for patient to have repeat 
bronchoscopy with biopsy as an outpatient.

indicative of ischemia. Left heart cath revealed no 
atherosclerosis. Her lipid profile was not abnormal. Other 
possibilities for her chest pressure include esophageal 
disorders (GERD, dysmotility, hiatal hernia), chest wall 
pathology, coronary vasospasm, lung/pleural disease. She did not 
receive further inpatient work up. She was discharged with 
nitroglycerin to see if this would improve recurrent symptoms at 
home.
