【14】Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE
.
Ms. ___ is a ___ lady with auto-immune hepatitis, DVT/PE, 
and steroid-induced DM who was transferred to ___ for high 
ammonia level and confusion which was concerning for hepatic 
encephalopathy.  However, by the time of arrival she was not 
encephalopathic.  She was continued on Lactulose, ruled out for 
significant portal vein thrombosis, and was discharged home.  
ACTIVE ISSUES
.
#. Confusion: Patient was probably slightly encephalopathic 
prior to arrival due to missing Lactulose doses, but she then 
received Lactulose and was not encephalopathic by the time she 
arrived. She had no asterixis and is A+O x3. Reliably answers 
the question "what is the year?" with ___,  I mean ___, I 
mean ___  However, in this woman on immunosuppressants, 
infectious cause of AMS were considered as well: UA and CXR at 
OSH were negative.  CT head at OSH was unremarkable.  Also, U/S 
abdomen with doppler was obtained to rule out portal vein 
thrombosis / hepatoma especially because T bili was slightly 
above baseline, though trended down.  The U/S showed a small 
eccentric nonocclusive distal main portal vein clot that was 
considered not to be of hemodynamic significance.  She was 
continued on Lactulose and was sent home with Hepatology 
followup.  
# Autoimmune Hepatitis: MELD 25, CP class B.
Patient with biopsy-proven cirrhosis, grade I varices, 
hypertensive gastropathy. Patient is on prednisone and 
azathioprine, with some recent dose changes. Her transaminases 
are improved since last admission.  She was continued on 
Prednisone 15mg QD, Azathioprine 100mg QD, Spironolactone 100mg 
BID, and Lasix 100mg QD. She will follow up with Hepatology.  
# IVC thrombus and h/o DVT: Patient with recent admission for 
thrombus proximal to IVC filter, at which point she was started 
on Coumadin.  Her INR was supratherapeutic (3.7) so her Coumadin 
was held.  Her dose was lowered and she was instructed to have 
her INR checked 3 days after discharge; this will be followed up 
by her PCP who will adjust the dose as needed (as it was prior 
to admission).  As described above, she did have a "small 
eccentric nonocclusive distal main portal vein clot that was 
considered not to be of hemodynamic significance" that was seen 
on U/S; she is adequately anticoagulated and will be seeing her 
Hepatologist in follow-up.  
INACTIVE ISSUES
.
# DM due to steroids: On glipizide at home. 
Switched to insulin sliding scale in house but resumed Glipizide 
upon discharge.  
# Asthma: stable
-Continued flonase and albuterol.  
.  
# Depression: stable

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

【25】Discharge Instructions:
You came to the hospital with abdominal pain and were found to 
have 2 hernias that were causing your pain and incarcerated a 
portion of your small bowel. You were taken to the operating 
room and had these hernias repaired. You are recovering well and 
are now being discharged home with the following instructions:

【26】Please follow up in ___ clinic at the appointment scheduled for 
you below. 

【27】ACTIVITY:

【28】Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first.

【29】HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 

【30】You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want to 
nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You 
might feel somewhat depressed.
You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.

【31】YOUR INCISION:
Your incision may be slightly red around the staples. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision. This will 
go away.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
Ove the next ___ months, your incision will fade and become 
less prominent.

【32】YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as 
Percocet or codeine. If needed, you may take a stool softener 
(such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk 
of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon.

【33】PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription from your surgeon for pain 
medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine 
as directied. Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do 
not take more medicine at one time than prescribed.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the folloiwng, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

【34】MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
In some cases you will have a prescription for antibiotics or 
other medication.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

【35】DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

【35】Brief Hospital Course:
Information for Outpatient Providers: ___ year old man with a 
history of atrial fibrillation on apixiban, vascular dementia, 
and recent aspiration pneumonia who presented following episodes 
of BRBPR. 

【36】#BRBPR. Patient presents from a facility with a few episodes of 
BRBPR, with stable hemodynamics and CBCs to date. CTA A/P 
without active extravasation but notable for concern for lower 
GI bleeding from diverticulosis vs AVM vs hemorroidal bleeding. 
Patient was evaluated by GI who felt that given his stable 
labs/hemodynamics and lack of significant bleeding while 
inpatient, the therapeutic potential of a sigmoidoscopy would be 
limited and therefore was deferred given his preferences per his 
HCP ___. His HCP/daughter did feel that the recent transition 
from Coumadin to Apixaban aggravated this bleed. Given deferral 
of endoscopic procedure, patient was restarted on his Apixaban 
but at a lower dose 2.5 mg BID given concern with bleeding at 
the higher dose (5 mg BID) and also low CHADS2VASC 3 (on it for 
history of atrial fibrillation). He was monitored on lower dose 
Apixaban for 2 days prior to discharge and did have minor 
bleeding streaked in with stools, however his CBCs and vital 
signs continued to remain stable. A bowel regimen to soften his 
stools was administered and efforts to reduce constipation and 
straining should be pursued in the future. 

【37】___ on CKD. Baseline Cr ~1.2, though has recently increased to 
1.5. Previously with urinary retention and poor po intake. He 
did receive 2L IVF with Cr stabilizing at 1.3 on discharge.

【38】#UTI. UA is concerning for infection and labs demonstrate a 
leukocytosis. Patient is poor historian given baseline dementia 
and unable to describe specific symptoms, however given 
leukocytosis, ceftriaxone was started and narrowed to 
ciprofloxacin given growth of pseudomonas, for a total five day 
course (last dose tonight).

【39】#Leukocytosis. No focal infectious etiology though patient is a 
poor historian. He did recently complete a course of abx with 
doxycycline on ___ for aspiration PNA. CXR on this admission 
without concerning features, though urine culture positive as 
above. Leukocytosis improved following initiation of Ceftriaxone 
(management as above). 

【40】#Hypertension. Patient's metoprolol should be restarted on 
discharge, initially held when there was concern for GI 
bleeding. 

【41】#Atrial fibrillation. CHADS2VASC 3. He had been transitioned 
from warfarin to apixiban about 2 weeks ago. He was restarted on 
lower dose apixaban 2.5 mg BID in the setting of bleed as above, 
given low CHADS2VASC. 

【42】#BPH. His home tamsulosin was continued.

【21】Brief Hospital Course:
# Hypertension:
At presentation, we considered  etiologies for acute change in 
blood pressure. CXR was unremarkable for widened mediastinum 
suggesting dissection was less likely. Also patient did not give 
a classic history of chest and back pain. In addition, cardiac 
enzymes were checked and were negative for two sets. After this 
work-up was completed, hypertension was thought to be most 
likely attributed to changes in blood pressure medications 
during last hospitalization. Given that HCTZ was discontinued 
due to concerns for gout and that the patient had been 
well-controlled on that medication, we initiated amlodipine at 5 
mg per day. This intervention had a noticeable effect on blood 
pressure at it was approximately 130 systolic at time of 
discharge. Patient was educated on importance of low salt diet 
and follow-up was arranged for her to have a BP check by a nurse 
practitioner on ___ and then follow-up with her PCP later 
that week. In regards to her urine dipstick showing mild 
proteinuria, it was noted that this is not a new finding and was 
attributed to damage caused by chronic hypertension.

【22】# HA:
Appears to be related to hypertension as headaches improved with 
control of blood pressure and when SBP was at ~130, patient had 
complete resolution of headache. At presentation Head CT was 
negative for intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect. History and 
exam did not otherwise suggest infectious process as she denied 
fever and chills and had no leukocytosis and a supple neck at 
presentation. Headaches are not consistent with migraines and 
patient denies excessive stress to suggest tension headaches. 
Goal for headache prevention in future should be focused on 
blood pressure control.

【23】# Gout:
No acute issues while hospitalized, though patient is not on 
allopurinol as an outpatient and would likely benefit from 
maintenance dose given her uric acid level of 6.8 on ___.

【24】# Glucose Intolerance:
Reported in history, but not on hypoglycemic agents as an 
outpatient. Fingersticks while hospitalized revealed 
post-prandial sugar of 166 and fasting sugar of 113 the morning 
following admission. Is not concerning for diabetes at this 
time.

【14】Brief Hospital Course:
In the ED, initial vital signs were T98.8 P60 BP119/67 R14 O2 
sat.98%
Patient was given IV morphine for pain. ECG and troponin were 
neg for ACS. She was admitted for management of her leg swelling 
and pain.       

【15】# LEG PAIN AND SWELLING: Given her chronic diastolic HF, 
congestion on CXR, her progressive SOB with exertion and her 6 
lb weight gain, she was felt to have worsening CHF. Her last 
ECHO was in ___, found to have EF >55%. She missed her dose of 
Torsemide the day prior to admission which may have acutely 
worsened her volume status. She admits that she misses doses 
occasionally if she won't be near a bathroom for several hours. 
The patient was restarted on torsemide and realized a net 1.5L 
diuresis on HD#2. Her torsemide was continued through the visit 
which improved both her lower extremity edema and SOB. She was 
provided with additional counseling about the importance of 
limiting salt and fluid intake and medication compliance.
# CHEST TIGHTNESS: Patient developed chest tightness while lying 
in hospital bed, and reported that she has had it intermittently 
over past few days, not associated with difficulty breathing, 
SOB or chest pain. She received an albuterol nebulizer with 
relief of symptom. Cardiac enzymes were neg X3. ECG had T wave 
inversions with some mild ST depressions, consistent with LV 
hypertrophy. She remained without chest symptoms the remainder 
of her hospital stay. The patient was questioned about her 
history of chest "tightness", pain, or pressure. She reported 
that she does occasionally have tightness with and without 
exertion as well as episodes of shortness of breath and 
diaphoresis. After discussion with PCP, it was determined that 
patient would not remain inpatient for stress testing and 
instead pursue testing as outpatient per PCP.
# WHEEZING, SOB: Symptoms are exertional and had been getting 
progressively worse for past week. CXR showed evidence of 
vascular congestion and pt appeared volume overloaded on 
clinical exam. She was treated with 200 mg Torsemide with 
resulting 2+ L diuresis overall. Pt remained asymptomatic during 
hospitalization.
# HYPOKALEMIA: Patient had mild ST depressions on ECG and a run 
of ventricular tachycardia. She received 40mg KCl to replete 
potential urinary K+ losses from diuresis. The hypokalemia 
resolved.
#Hypoglycemia/Diabetes: Patient with generally well-controlled 
diabetes at home, last A1c was 6.4%. Her fasting sugars while 
inpatient were tight around 110-140. Her metformin was held 
while admitted and she was placed on sliding scale insulin. She 
did have one episode of asymptomatic hypoglycemia to 47 that was 
identified during routine FBS check and it was treated with 
juice and rechecked.
Chronic Issues:
# OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA: Patient uses CPAP nightly at home. 
She brought her unit into the hospital and used it while 
inpatient.
# HYPERTENSION: BP 143/79 on admission, down to 100s-130s/60s 
after 2 L diuresis with torsemide. Her torsemide and enalapril 
were continued and she was discharged on these medications.
# HYPERLIPIDEMIA: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia. 
She was continued on her home statin while inpatient.
### TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- Evaluate diuretic regimen
- Consider rheumatologic w/u for generalized body aches and 
joint pain/stiffness that is worse upon waking

triamcinilone and emollient therapy as barrier protection. She 
had workup and treatment for CHF as below. By discharge leg pain 
and swelling had significantly improved.

【31】#CHF: Given peripheral lower extremity edema and chronic venous

【17】Brief Hospital Course:
___ w/ hx depression and multiple suicide attmepts presents 
after suicide attempt by ingestion of Soma. 
.
Active Diagnoses:
# Ingestion - Pt had a sedative toxodrome with obtundation, 
likely Soma. As per Toxicology, "Soma is considered a skeletal 
muscle relaxant but likely works by agonizing GABA.Jerking 
motions are common s/p carisoprodol ingestions, likely due to 
myoclonic jerks. These should be self limiting.If jerking 
motions are not self-limiting upon paralysis wearing off, 
probably reasonable to rule out sz activity w/ EEG, though this 
would not likely be from a Soma ingestion."  ASA, APAP, ETOH 
screens were negative.  Patient was able to be weaned from 
midazolam and extubated within an hour of arriving to the MICU.  
When extubated, she reported that she had taken 15 Soma (unknown 
strength) at around 2pm as a suicide attempt.  She denies any 
other ingestion.  She did not have spontaneous myoclonus in the 
MICU, but initially had clonus when elicited on exam; this 
resolved within 12 hours. Her initial EKG looks WNL (sinus), and 
there was no evidence of MAO-I ingestion.  Repeat labs are WNL.  
Especially given possible aspiration, the patient's respiratory 
status was monitored after intubation.  No respiratory distress, 
fever, or elevated WBC. Repeat EKG was reassuring.  Patient was 
given PO thiamine.  She complained of pleuritic chest pain and 
cough the morning after the ingestion, but her lungs were clear 
on exam, she was sat-ing well on room on air, and she was not 
tachypneic.  CXR was WNL and showed no acute cardiopulmonary 
process.  
.
# Medical Clearance for Psychiatric Hospitalization - The 
patient was intubated and possibly aspirated, but we do not 
believe she currently has a PNA .  If she develops 
fever or SOB, she may need to be evaluated for PNA, but right 
now she is medically cleared.  She is eating, drinking, and is 
able to tolerate normal physical activity.
# Hypothroidism (?) - Chronic diagnosis.  Patient reports that 
she's on Synthroid 50mcg at home, but husband and psychiatrist 
report that she is not as per psychiatry.  She was given one 
dose of Synthroid 50mcg the morning after her ingestion, as we 
did not know the patient was no longer on this medicaiton.  She 
then developed tachycardia to 110.  We initially thought this 
was related to volume depletion and/or anxiety, and she was 
given 1L LR.  TSH level was sent before she was given the 
Synthroid and is still pending.  When we realized she is no 
longer on this medication, it was discontinued. 
.
# Suicidality/Anxiety/Depression - Ingestion was suicide 
attempt.  Psychiatry was consulted and recommended inpatient 
psychiatric hospitalization.  The patient had a 1-to-1 sitter 
while in the MICU.  Her home Cymbalta, lorazepam, trazodone, 
Ambien, and prazosin (for nightmares) were continued.  Her home 
dextroamphetamine was held.
# Transitional Issues
- Pending TSH study.  Unclear significance, given critical 
illness and intubation.  Recommend rechecking in 6 weeks.

【24】Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o F with PMHx of recent "cellulitis" who presents with 
acute onset of papules that progressed into erythematous/swollen 
rash over her right forearm and right lower leg. Due to concern 
for rapidly progressing cellulitis, pt was sent to the ED and 
started on empiric Vancomycin/Ancef.   Pt was afebrile without 
leukocytosis or infectious symptoms.   The rash continues to 
progress on Abx and dermatology was consulted due to atypical 
history nature of the rash.  Pt underwent a biopsy on ___ and 
she was started on anti-histamines with topical steroids.    By 
the morning, the rash was starting to improve and antibiotics 
were stopped.   Pt was noted to have a peripheral eosinophilia 
and the prelim result of the biopsy was most suggestive of an 
eosinophilic cellulitis (wells syndrome).   All culture data was 
negative for growth and pt remained afebrile with some 
improvement in symptoms.  It was felt that her presentation was 
not consistent with an infectious cellulitis so she was 
discharged home with a prescription for Triamcinolone, 
Fexofenadine and plan for close follow up with dermatology for 
final biopsy results.

continued to progress clinically and was transferred to the

protocol.  He worked with physical therapy on strength and 
mobility.  He continued to do well and was ready for discharge 
home with services on post operative day four.

【23】# Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely caused by volume 
overload in the setting of CKD V, mild sCHF (EF ~45%) and 2+ MR. 
___ if patient developed flash pulmonary edema in the 
setting of hypertension. Pt w/troponin of 0.03 (baseline 0.02) 
and had no EKG changes, making ACS unlikely trigger. PNA was 
considered given CXR and slight leukocytosis, although much less 
likely given lack of fever. Pt was given Zosyn in the ED, but 
additional abx held. Pt was intubated for increased WOB shortly 
after arrival into the CCU. She was aggressively diuresed and 
extubated on ___, post-extubation she had an episode of 
stridorous upper airway sounds; she was given nebs + racemic 
epi; stridor on exam, the symptoms appear positional, better 
when leaning forward. ENT performed a scope which was normal. 
She was not striderous at the time. Satting well on 2L NC and 
40% FiO2 by face tent. No edema or vocal cord dysfunction. No 
further episodes of stridor occured. Her oxygen was titrated 
down and she was able to ambulate without difficulty on room air 
at her time of discharge.

【24】# Volume overload: Pt appeared to be volume overloaded on exam, 
although this was not particularly impressive. As above, it is 
likely that she flashed, and the precipitant is likely to be 
HTN. Renal was consulted and followed patient throughout. 
Otherwise she was aggressively diuresed with IV lasix and 
metolazone, and transitioned to PO lasix prior to discharge with 
good urinary output and improvement in symptoms.  She was 
discharged on a regimen of 120mg PO Lasix.

【25】# Stage V CKD: Pt s/p fistula placement on ___, and per 
nephrology notes, this is now OK to use. Pt diuresed fairly well 
with IV lasix, but may ultimately need HD soon. Strict I/Os were 
kept with Foley. Medications were renally dosed for CrCl < 15. 
Her inpatient and outpatient providers decided to initiate 
hemodialysis given her multiple episodes of pulmonary edema, and 
she had five cycles of HD as an inpatient.  She was set up with 
an outpatient dialysis schedule prior to discharge.  Her home 
sodium bicarbonate, sevelamer, calcitriol, and ferrous sulfate 
were discontinued after dialysis initiation. Hepatitis 
serologies and TB testing were initiated prior to HD, and she 
was found to be Hep B negative (prior exposure, Core antibody 
positive, surface antibody positive, surface antigen negative) 
and C negative and had a negative PPD.

After transfer from ICU, patient was initiated on HD, and 
amlodipine and hydralazine were discontinued given the 
improvement in her blood pressures. She was discharged on 
Carvedilol and Imdur. It is imperative that she stagger these 
medications throughout the day so that she does not become 
dizzy. Her outpatient blood pressure regimen was discussed with 
the renal team and is as follows:

【15】Brief Hospital Course:
1. Acute Back Pain: Ms. ___ was admitted for back pain likely 
secondary to L3-L4 disc herniation with impingement of her L3 
nerve root leading to worsening radicular symptoms radiating 
down left extremity to left knee. She was evaluated in the ED by 
___ who recommended L-Spine Xray and admission for pain 
management.  No neurological compromise was demonstrated. She 
had a chronic decreased rectal tone and perianal paresthesia 
secondary to a history of Pudendal Nerve entraptment which was 
being treated with corticosteroid injections by her OBGYN; there 
were no new neurological changes consistent with cauda equina. 
Plain knee films were obtained of the left knee given her pain 
however there was no evidence of inflammation or fracture.  Pain 
management was initiated with IV dilaudid; she also had several 
home medications, including percoset for her chronic pudendal 
pain, which we discontinued but which made her relatively 
resistant to the effects of the dilaudid. Given her refractory 
pain, neurosurgery decided to intervene: they performed a 
diskectomy of L4 and foramenotomy; following the surgery she 
became mildly hypotensive and dizzy with relief with IV fluids.  
Following the surgery, an oral pain medicine regimen was 
established that seemed to provide relief: oral steroids (a 
medrol pack) to decrease inflammation, oxycontin 20 mg BID, PO 
dilaudid ___ mg PO q3 hours, naproxyn 500 BID, nortrpytiline 25 
mg qhs, and gabapentin 300 mg TID.  She was discharged with her 
pain relatively controlled and follow-up set up with 
neurosurgery for repeat MRI and evaluation in 6 weeks.
2.Hypothyroidism - We continued home levoxyl.

【22】Discharge Instructions:
You were diagnosed with an L4 disk herniation compressing nerve 
roots and causing back pain and pain radiating down your left 
leg and foot.  We admitted you to make sure that you had no 
other concerning neurological symptoms from spine compression.  
Based on the X-rays that we took and the evaluation the 
neurosurgeons performed, we did not detect any concerning 
neurological symptoms.  The X-rays also suggested that you did 
not have any fractures.  We attempted to treat your severe pain 
with IV medications, including Dilaudid and toradol, however, 
your pain did not improve significantly.  We increased the doses 
of these medicines with some effect.  Given that your pain 
continued to be severe, neurosurgery decided to intervene.  They 
performed a microdiskectomy, in which they removed the bulging 
disk, relieveing the pressure on the compressed nerve.  This 
should improve your pain considerably, both in your low back and 
the pain radiating down your left leg.  When you return home, 
you are likely to continue to experience pain; it will take time 
for the pain to resolve.  We have sent you home with several 
pain medications as well as steroids which will help decrease 
inflammation.  All medicine changes are listed below as follows:
通用删除7(英):<u>(1)</u> You should stop taking all percosets that you take at home.

通用删除7(英):<u>(3)</u> Take nortryptiline 25 mg at bedtime.
通用删除7(英):<u>(4)</u> Take oxycontin 25 mg twice a day.
通用删除7(英):<u>(5)</u> Take naproxen 500 mg twice a day.
通用删除7(英):<u>(6)</u> Continue to take your steroid pack as directed.
通用删除7(英):<u>(7)</u> If you continue to experience pain on this regimen, you can 
take an oral dilaudid ___ mg; at maximum you can take this every 
three hours, but you should limit its use.
If you experience any sleepiness or if you notice that you are 
having trouble with breathing, you should stop taking pain 
medicines and call your primary care doctor for further 
direction.  These medicines can sedate you and lower your 
respiratory rate, so it is very important to take these 
medicines as directed and carefully.  
.
You can continue your other home medications but please 
discontinue percocet.
We encourage you to ambulate frequently; avoid bedrest as this 
can make back pain worse.  Gentle, frequent walking is useful; 
over-exercise and under-exercise are both detrimental.  
.
If you experience any new symptoms, chest pain, shortness of 
breath, or any other concerning symptoms, please call your 
primary care physician or return to the emergency department.  
It's important to remember that your pain is likely to be 
persistent for several days and it may increase at times and go 
away at others; don't panic: try to adhere to your medication 
regimen.  If your pain continues to be persistently severe, 
please call your primary care physician.

【78】Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

【79】Brain Hemorrhage with Surgery

【80】Surgery

【81】·     You underwent a surgery called a craniotomy to remove 
damaged brain tissue and to have blood removed from your brain. 
·     It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok 
to cover it when outside. 

【82】·     Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

【83】Activity

【84】·     We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, 
climbing, or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up 
appointment.

【85】·     You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.

【86】·     No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating 
medication. 

【87】·     If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 

【88】·     No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

【89】Medications

【90】·     Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 

【91】·     You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time. 

【92】·     You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort 
if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

【93】What You ___ Experience:

【94】·     You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, 
and remembering new information.

【95】·     Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 

【96】·     Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.

【97】·     You may also experience some post-operative swelling 
around your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 

【98】·     You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal 
from the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 

【99】·     Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids 
and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics 
(prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool 
softener.

【100】Headaches:

【101】·     Headache is one of the most common symptoms after a brain 
bleed. 

【102】·     Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 

【103】·     Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches 
but avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless 
prescribed by your doctor. 

【104】·     There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 

【105】When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:

【106】·     Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the 
incision site. 

【107】·     Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

【108】·     Nausea and/or vomiting

【109】·     Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake

【110】·     Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers

【111】·     Seizures

【112】·     Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak

【113】·     Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or 
leg

【114】Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:

【115】·     Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg

【116】·     Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding

【117】·     Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination

【118】·     Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

PERFORMED ON

【14】Comparison is made with a prior CT abdomen and pelvis from

【15】CLINICAL HISTORY: ___ woman with atrial fibrillation, on 
Coumadin, 
presents with cold mottled left leg, question of arterial 
occlusion. 

【16】TECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT was used to obtain contiguous axial 
images 
through the abdomen, pelvis and both lower extremities, first 
without and then with IV contrast with imaging performed during 
arterial phase. Additional imaging through the lower legs at a 
slight delay was also provided.  Multiplanar reformations as 
well as 3D MIP and curved reformats were provided. 

【17】FINDINGS: 

【18】CTA: Non-contrast imaging demonstrates extensive atherosclerotic 

【19】calcification along the abdominal aorta, iliac branches 
extending into the 
arterial branches of the lower extremities. Following the 
administration of IV contrast, there is brisk opacification of 
the abdominal aorta with patency of the celiac artery, SMA, 
renal arteries and ___. The aorta is somewhat tortuous, there is 
no aneurysmal dilation. There is progressive narrowing of the 
lumen of the infrarenal abdominal aorta and complete occlusion 
just beyond the takeoff of the inferior mesenteric artery. The 
aorta remains completely occluded through the bifurcation with 
occlusion of the common iliac arteries bilaterally. There is 
reconstitution of the bilateral common iliac branches within the 
pelvis. On the right, there is patency of the right external 
iliac artery and distal branches into the right lower extremity. 
However, on the left, there is occlusion of the left proximal 
superficial femoral artery just distal to the takeoff of the 
profunda branch. There is no distal reconstitution of the left 
superficial femoral artery or distal branches into the left 
lower extremity. 

【20】ABDOMEN: The liver enhances normally without definite sign of 
focal lesion on 
this arterial phase exam. The gallbladder, atrophic pancreas, 
and adrenal 
glands appear unremarkable. There is a small hypodensity in the 
spleen which is new from prior study most compatible with a 
cyst. The kidneys enhance symmetrically without focal worrisome 
lesion. There is no retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.  

【21】The stomach is decompressed. 

【22】PELVIS: Loops of small and large bowel demonstrate no signs of 
ileus or 
obstruction. There is a lobulated solid mass in the left adnexa 
measuring 
approximately 10.4 (AP) x 6.4 (transverse) x 6.8 (craniocaudal 
dimension) cm . 
This mass was seen on the prior exam though has decreased in 
size in the 
interval and is of unknown etiology though diagnostic 
considerations include an exophytic fibroid versus ovarian mass. 
There are extensive calcifications within the myometrium of the 
uterus. There is no right adnexal mass. The urinary bladder 
contains a small amount of gas which could be iatrogenic and 
clinical correlation is advised. There is no free pelvic fluid. 
No pelvic side wall lymphadenopathy. 

【23】BONES: No worrisome lytic or blastic osseous lesion is seen. 
Bones are 
demineralized. Mild anterior wedging of T12 vertebral body is 
noted.

femoral artery without distal reconstitution.

cultures to rule out drug effects and infection revealed a 
urinary tract infection and the patient had been given her usual 
dose of Ativan prior to becoming agitated. She was given empiric 
antibiotic treatment until sensitivities returned and showed 
that she has resistant E. coli; she was subsequently started on 
Zosyn which requires intravenous administration, for a 7 day 
course in total. Pain was initially managed with a PCA and then 
transitioned to oral Roxicet once tolerating a stage 2 diet.

standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. The patient continued to 
require oxygen via nasal canula given her pulmonary 
comorbidities.

advanced sequentially to a low fat diet, which was well 
tolerated. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored.  
JP output remained serosanguinous throughout admission; the

infection, of which there were none. She remained afebrile, but 
had surgical site erythema and drainage for several days on the 
floor. The sites were opened, drained and packed with wet gauze.

continues to require dressing changes and wound packing, but is 
otherwise healing as expected.

【14】Brief Hospital Course:
# Acute onset dyspnea: Patient has been intermittently dyspneic 
at home and her Lasix and supplemental O2 seems to have relieved 
this shortness of breath in the past.  This response most likely 
indicates pulmonary edema as the cause, but the differential dx 
for shortness of breath includes cardiac ischemia/MI, PNA (esp 
aspiration), PE, PTX, and COPD exacerbation ___ smoking hx). 
CXR did not reveal any infiltrates indicative of PNA and did 
have vascular congestion + BNP >6000. Cardiac enzymes have been 
negative and level x3.  Her shortness of breath improved with 
diuresis on Lasix 20mg PO and she required minimal oxygen (0.5L) 
to maintain adequate saturation. A repeat CXR prior to discharge 
did not show iterval change, though had poor inspiratory effort. 
The pt uses O2 at home for exertion only though will be 
discharged on O2 at rest as well to help maintain oxygenation.

【15】.
# Urinary tract infection: Previous urine culture done earlier 
in the week showed Proteus mirabilis, resistant to Cipro. She 
was originally taking Cipro and was changed to cefuroxime.  She 
received 1 dose prior to admission. Repeat UA done in ED still 
consistent with UTI. Patient started on ceftriaxone IV but 
switched to cefuroxime PO to take for 10 more days after 
discharge.  Urine culture done in the ED is negative. Per the 
son, pt had a history of large left kidney stone ___ years ago, a 
renal ultrasound was ordered before the pt went home with a 
follow-up scheduled with urology at ___ later this month.

【16】.
# Altered mental status: The patient was somnolent/confused and 
not following commands. Her mental status waxed and waned.  Per 
her son, this is not her baseline.  Head CT was negative.  
Potential etiologies include hypercarbia (though she is likely a 
chronic CO2 retainer) vs infection. Per Dr. ___, she is 
quite sensitive to infections and the treatment of her urinary 
tract infection is the best way to bring her back to her 
baseline.  Upon discharge, the pt was more alert and oriented 
though still had difficulty speaking, likely a combination of 
baseline mental status and dysarthria or difficulty without 
dentures. 
.
# Acute kidney injury: Creatinine bumped to 1.5, with a baseline 
of 1.0.  Given response to Lasix, this decreased kidney function 
was likely due to poor forward flow/perfusion secondary to 
diastolic CHF exacerbation. Before discharge, Cr improved to 1.2 
and then to 1.0.
# Hypernatremia: 140 -> 147 -> 143 -> 140.  This was likely due 
to decreased PO intake at home and improved with an increased 
appetite in the hospital.
# Atrial Fibrillation: On warfarin and metoprolol tartrate. INR 
was stable throughout hospitalization after warfarin was 
down-titrated to 2mg from a home dose of 4mg. Pt's INR prior to 
discharge was 1.7 so her dose was increased back to home dose of 
4mg daily. She will need close follow-up of INR to maintain 
therapeutic range.

【46】Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old woman with a PMH of chronic 
abdominal pain, hereditary hemorrhagic teleangiectasia with 
gastric and duodenal AVMS, iron deficiency anemia transfusion 
dependent via port-a-cath (last transfusion ___), DVT (s/p IVC 
filter ___, IDDM, HFpEF, COPD, OSA on home BiPAP who presented 
with altered mental status, fall, abdominal pain, dysuria, in 
MICU for <1 day, treated for acute on chronic HFpEF with severe 
RV dysfunction, UTI, also noted to have subacute infarcts on 
non-contrast head CT concerning for embolic CVA events.

【47】ACTIVE ISSUES: 
==============
# Bilateral embolic cerebrovascular accidents 
Given fall and concern that patient had altered mental status, 
CT head was ordered upon admission. Patient found to have 
subacute hypodensity on CT head, concerning for stroke. An MRI 
head was obtained and showed multiple, bilateral, embolic 
strokes that were acute to subacute in nature. Patient was 
started on rosuvastatin 40mg daily but was unable to be 
initiated on aspirin therapy given her history of HHT/bleeding 
risk. Patient's outpatient hematologist was involved in this 
discussion and confirmed that her bleeding risk, chronic RBC 
transfusion dependence, and chronic iron infusion dependence 
made her a poor candidate for indefinite anticoagulation or 
antiplatelet agents of any kind (including long duration baby 
aspirin). Neurology was consulted on ___ for assistance with 
further stroke work-up. Patient was monitored on telemetry for 
evidence of atrial fibrillation and was found to have no acute 
arrhythmia. Implantation of a loop recorder was discussed, but 
the decision was made to defer this; if atrial fibrillation were 
to be identified, the patient is not a candidate for 
anticoagulation, however one could consider surgical vs. 
percutaneous left atrial appendage occlusion.  However, afib was 
felt less likely to be the culprit of her ongoing strokes.  
Carotid ultrasound showed less than 40% internal carotid 
disease, bilaterally. A CTA head/neck was obtained and was 
negative for significant carotid artery or circle of ___ 
vessel disease. Further work-up for lower extremity deep vein 
thrombosis with LENIS and CTV pelvis (to evaluate her IVC 
filter) were both negative. Patient underwent TTE with bubble 
study and was found to have a large patent foramen ovale with 
severe right ventricular dysfunction. A follow-up TEE with 
bubble study showed that there was a continuous right to left 
shunt through the PFO.  TEE read shows no definitive evidence of 
early bubbles entering the left atrium from the pulmonary veins 
(however on repeat read with various imaging cardiologists, this 
cannot be definitiely ruled out).  It is possible that she is 
having paradoxical emboli via pulmonary AV malformations, 
however the degree of shunting via PFO vs. pulmonary AVMs is 
unknown a this time. Cardiac surgery was consulted to discuss 
surgical PFO closure.  There was concern as to whether she would 
be an optimal surgical candidate.  Pt. was eager to be 
discharged from the hospital to take care of various personal 
matters.  Interdisciplinary discussions occurred with 
hematology, cardiology, structural cardiology, cardiac surgery, 
neurology, and pulmonary hypertension.  Pt. will be seen as an 
outpatient and likely re-admitted within a week to have ongoing 
diuresis, assessment of her pulmonary hypertension, 
consideration of pulmonary vasodilator therapy pending degree of 
pre vs. post capillary pulmonary hypertension, and then 
consideration of percutaneous PFO closure at that time.  The 
patient's hematologist, was included in these discussions and 
recommended that anti-platelet therapy with aspirin for ___ 
months would be acceptable based on pt's ongoing risk of stroke.

【48】# Acute on chronic HFpEF 
Patient presents with elevated pro-BNP, weight gain, CXR with 
pulmonary vascular congestion, and evidence of volume overload 
on exam, consistent with CHF exacerbation. Unclear trigger, 
possibly in the setting of dietary indiscretion vs. medication 
non-compliance vs. infection secondary to UTI . Other 
possibilities include ischemia, though unlikely given absence of 
angina type symptoms and ST changes on ECG. Received IV diuresis 
then was transitioned to PO torsmide 80mg daily. She initially 
received her home lisinopril for afterload reduction, but this 
medication was discontinued in the setting of hyperkalemia. She 
was started on amlodipine 5mg daily after discontinuation of 
lisinopril. Upon discharge, pt did have evidence ___ edema and 
is unlikely to be at her dry weight .

【49】# Abdominal pain 
Patient presented with ___ LLQ pain that was worse with eating 
certain foods. She had a CT A&P that was negative for ischemic 
colitis or other acute pathologies, and a lactate was within 
normal limits. Her abdominal exam was benign. Patient was 
treated with Tylenol and oxycodone as needed for her pain. She 
refused her home gabapentin. 

【50】# Acute kidney injury
Creatinine elevated to 1.7 on presentation, from baseline 1.0. 
Thought to be cardiorenal in the setting of volume overload, and 
initially improved with diuresis back to 1.0. Patient's 
creatinine fluctuated between 1.0-1.3 throughout admission. 
Creatinine on day of discharge was 1.2.

【51】# Urinary tract infection
Patient presented with several days of dysuria and was found to 
have dirty UA. She was started on vancomycin and cefepime in the 
ED on ___ and narrowed to ceftriaxone on ___ for treatment 
of a UTI. Her urine cultures ultimately were positive for 
proteus mirabilis. 

【52】# Troponemia
Elevated trop 0.___hanges on ECG. Unlikely to be 
ischemia. Most likely secondary to decreased renal clearance in 
the setting of acute kidney injury. 

【53】# Elevated D-dimer
Patient found to have slightly elevated D-dimer in ED, which was 
initially obtained to rule-out PE in the setting of patient's 
acute kidney injury. She had no symptoms or vital sign 
abnormalities suggestive of acute PE, so a V/Q scan and CTPA 
were not obtained. Additionally, she has several medical 
comorbidities that could explain her mildly elevated D-dimer. 

【54】# Possible alcohol use disorder
Reportedly, family called patient during her time in the MICU 
and expressed concen about alcohol use. Per patient, she does 
not drink alcohol at all, and serum/urine toxin screen was 
negative for EtOH on admission. She had no signs of withdrawal 
during her admission. 

【55】# Encephalopathy 
Noted to have altered mental status in ED that resolved upon 
transfer to the floor. Neurologic work up is noted above given 
abnormal CT head. Possible etiologies include reduced clearance 
of gabapentin in the setting of acute kidney injuy vs. infection 
in setting of known urinary tract infection.

【69】Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,

【70】WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL? 
- You were admitted to the hospital because you were having 
stomach pain and pain with urination. 
- You were found to have too much fluid in your body and were 
admitted to the intensive care unit to help remove some of the 
extra fluid with a medicine called Lasix.

【71】WHAT WAS DONE FOR YOU IN THE HOSPITAL? 
- You had a cat scan of your stomach which was normal. This is 
good news!
- You had a cat scan of your head which showed you had a stroke 
in the past. 
- You had an imaging test called an MRI to help us get a better 
look at the area of your brain where the stroke occurred. 
- You had an ultrasound of your heart, which showed you had a 
hole in your heart. A clot (clump of blood) likely passed 
through this hole and traveled to your brain, causing your 
stroke. The cardiac surgeons evaluated you to determine if this 
hole should be repaired.  They would like to see you in clinic 
after you leave the hospital to continue this discussion. 
- You were treated with Lasix (diuretic) to help remove the 
extra fluid in your body. 
- You had an infection in your urine that was treated with 
antibiotics. 
- Your stomach pain was treated with pain medications. 

【72】WHAT SHOULD YOU DO WHEN YOU GO HOME? 
- You should continue taking your medications, as prescribed. 
Your home torsemide dose was changed from 20mg daily to 80mg 
daily. You were started on rosuvastatin 40mg daily to help 
reduced your risk of stroke by keeping your cholesterol low.  
- You should weigh yourself every morning and call your doctor 
if your weight increases by more than 3 lbs. Your weight on the 
day you left the hospital was 190.19 lbs. 
- You should restrict the amount of fluid you drink to less than 
2 liters per day, and should consume less than 2 grams of salt 
per day. This will prevent fluid from building up in your body. 
- You should follow up with your primary care physician and 
cardiologist. You should follow up with cardiac surgery, who 
will determine whether you need a procedure to fix the hole in 
your heart. You should also follow up with your neurologist and 
hematology-oncologist. Your appointment information is below.
- You should have your blood drawn on the morning of ___ to 
ensure that your blood count is not too low. Your hematologist 
will decide whether or not you need a blood transfusion. 

【73】It was a pleasure taking care of you, and we wish you all the 
best!

【26】2. Safety: Mr. ___ was admitted in the context of active

【27】3. PSYCHIATRIC
#) ETOH WITHDRAWAL: Mr. ___ was maintained on a valium 
taper using CIWA protocol while in the ED which was completed 
after his first day of admission. He was also provided with 
daily thiamine, folate and multivitamins. 

【28】#) ETOH DEPENDENCE: Pt has a long standing history of alcohol 
dependence. We spent significant time counseling him on the need 
for alcohol cessation as this puts him at elevated risk for 
unsafe and dangerous behaviors as well as cognitive dysfunction, 
liver failure and potentially death. Referring pt to Adcare for 
rehab. Encouraged AA/rehab. Patient routinely requested antabuse 
for long term maintenance but stated no outside provider would 
provide this. Reviewed contraindications of antabuse which 
included cerebral disease and liver dysfunction and thus he was 
not provided with antabuse. Discussed option of acamprosate 
which patient said he had used before and would accept so he was 
provided with a medication. 

【29】#) DELIRIUM: Upon admission, Mr. ___ demonstrated 
significant confusion. Imaging in the ED was reviewed with 
neurology who identified indications of normal pressure 
hydrocephalus and recommended follow up for a large volume tap 
and monitoring as an outpatient. The differential diagnosis for 
Mr. ___ delirium is broad (etoh withdrawal, 
encephalopathy, wernicke's encephalits, korsakoff's psychosis, 
NPH) and is likely related to a combination of these factors. He 
was detoxed off etoh but continued to show signs of poor memory, 
lability and confusion likely representing underlying disease. 
Follow up with neurology has been made and he will be discharged 
back to the RES sober home. 

【30】#) MILIEU/GROUPS

behaviors. The pt ate all meals in the milieu, slept well, and 
cooperated with unit rules.

fevers/chills and abdominal pain. Her exam was significant for a 
temperature of 102, tachycardia with a heart rate of 122, and 
right costovertebral angle tenderness. Sterile speculum exam was 
deferred. She was found to have a urinary tract infection 
positive for E.coli culture and was admitted for IV antibiotics 
with ceftriaxone.

and cervical motion tenderness. Sterile speculum exam was

discharge. Renal and pelvic ultrasound were done which were

with white blood cell count of 11.6 with a left shift of 7

【12】Given the continued fevers and new exam findings, she was

provided sufficient coverage for the e.coli UTI/pyelonephritis.

leukocytosis resolved with no additional fevers after initiation 
of triple antibiotics.  

【13】By hospital day 3, she was afebrile with stable vitals signs.

stable condition to complete a 7-day antibiotic course for 
pyelonephritis.

regular.

【21】Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___:

【22】*  Your injury caused 1 rib fracture which can cause severe pain 
and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of 
the pain.

【23】*  You should take your pain medication as directed to stay 
ahead of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep 
breaths. If the pain medication is too sedating take half the 
dose and notify your physician.

【24】*  Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.

【25】*  You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to 
hold against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing 
and deep breathing.

【26】*  Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.

【27】*  Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.

【28】*  Do NOT smoke

【29】*  If your doctor allows, non steroidal antiinflammatory drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.

【30】*  Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs ( crepitus ).

【32】----Risk Assessment
This patient has a low to moderate risk of imminent danger to 
himself or others. The patient has numerous protective factors 
including a longstanding history of help seeking behaviors, a 
supportive living environment, a busy social calendar, close 
mental health followup, no active or recent substance abuse, no 
access to weapons or guns. Still he does have numerous risk 
factors including his age, race, gender, and marital status as 
well as his distant history of a suicide attempt as a teen, as 
well as the burden or both chronic mental and medical illness. 
While in the hospital we addressed his modifiable risk factors, 
namely his decompensated schizoaffective disorder. We worked 
with the patient to identify social isolation as primary trigger 
for his suicidal ideations and on the unit engaged him both in 
personalized as well as group therapy regarding such. We also 
ensured he had a busy social calendar with many planned social 
interactions upon discharge. Still given the static nature of 
many of the patient's risk factors such as his demographics, 
past suicide attempt, and chronic medical and mental illness, 
upon discharge the patient does remain at an elevated risk of 
self harm or suicide but no longer presents an imminent danger 
to himself requiring inpatient level of care.

【31】You were admitted to the gynecology service after your

【32】General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina for 6 weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

【33】Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.
* Do ___ baths once or twice day for to help ensure optimal 
healing and comfort of vulvar excision
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

【24】Brief Hospital Course:
___ yoF w/ a h/o DM II, HTN, and large B cell lymphoma DAY ___ s/p

【25】# Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain originally was of 
unclear etiology as she had no LFT abnormalities.  Her CT 
abdomen/pelvis showed diverticuli and very mild stranding, but 
no definite diverticulitis though the stranding was present on 
previous CT scans. The patient had been constipated for a few 
days prior to admission, and during her hospitalization, she had 
a difficult time moving her bowels.  An xray showed stool with 
evidence of a colonic ileus.  She was given stool softeners, and 
eventually she had a few bowel movements with marked improvement 
of her abdominal pain.  She did not have any fevers, or other 
evidence to concern for perforation or diverticulitis.  Her pain 
was initially controlled with IV morphine, but prior to 
discharge, she was switched to PO oxycodone with pain control.  
She was on cefipime during her hospitalization for the concern 
of potential infection, but prior to discharge, it was 
discontinued since her pain improved with bowel movements.  She 
was able to tolerate POs prior to discharge. 

【26】# LARGE B CELL LYMPHOMA: The patient had a recent diagnosis of 
large B cell lymphoma, and on admission she was day ___ s/p CHOP. 
There was improvement of her mass on CT. She was neutropenic 
during this admission, but with G-CSF, at the time of discharge, 
her ANC was >1000.  She will followup in clinic for further 
management as an outpatient.  

【27】# Urinary retention: The patient initially had some urinary 
retention after being given morphine, but with subsequent doses, 
it resolved.  She had no issues with urination afterwards 
throughout this hospitalization. 

【28】# HTN: The patient will continue Verapamil and Lisinopril, but 
her lisinopril was increased to 10 mg daily at discharge.  This 
will need to be followed up by her PCP.  

【29】# Diabetes: Patient will continue her metformin and glyburide.

【33】ACUTE ISSUES
============
# Staph Epidermitis Bacteremia: Patient presented with subacute 
symptoms of fevers and night sweats concerning for infection. 
CXR unremarkable, CT of abdomen and pelvis was negative for 
intra-abdominal infectious process. US spleen showed no focal 
lesions or evidence of infarction. Transthoracic echo was 
negative for vegetations, and patient had no cardiac murmurs on 
exam. Blood culture was found to be positive for Staph 
epidermitis, and patient was started on nafcillin following 
speciation. Given high grade bacteremia and the prolonged 
symptoms of fatigue he had prior to admission, even with a 
negative TTE, the concern for endocarditis remained high. 
However, trans-esophageal echo was considered too risky given 
patient's ongoing requirement of oxygen and thrombocytopenia. 
With consultation from infectious disease, decision was made to 
empirically treat patient for endocarditis. Patient remained 
afebrile and subsequent blood cultures were negative. Patient is 
to continue nafcillin 2 g IV Q4H for a total of 4 weeks (last 
day ___.

【34】# Essential Thrombocytopenia/Anemia/Thrombocytopenia: Patient's 
presentation of subacute fevers, nightsweats, 50lb weight loss 
and WBC of 20.8 on admission was concerning for transformation 
to acute leukemia. Patient was found to have 9% blasts on 
peripheral flow cytometry. Bone marrow biopsy found <5% of 
blasts; results consistent with myelofibrosis post-JAK2 V617F 
positive essential thrombocythemia. Anemia and thrombocytopenia 
most likely secondary to myelofibrosis as pt had no evidence of 
bleeding or hemolysis. Massively enlarged spleen (30.9 cm on CT) 
most likely resulted from extra-medullary hematopoesis. Jackafi 
5 mg PO BID was started and patient responded well to treatment. 
Patient received a total of 7 units pRBC during this 
hospitalization. At discharge patient's hemoglobin is 8.7 (s/p 
2U pRBC on ___. 

【35】# Acute on Chronic Hypoxemic Respiratory Distress: Patient was 
hypoxic, tachypnic, and required 4L oxygen at admission. CTA of 
chest was negative for PE. Patient had no symptoms or imaging 
consistent with pulmonary infectious process. PPD was negative. 
Etiology multifactorial and includes volume overload and 
restrictive etiology due to compression from massively enlarged 
spleen. Patient's respiratory status improved with diuresis and 
initiation of Jackafi. At discharge patient saturated well on 
room air and did not require oxygen supplementation, though 
intermittently requiring ___ O2 in the few days prior to 
discharge. Discharge ambulatory sat 91%/RA. 

【36】# Severe protein calorie malnutrition. Patient had history of 
decreased oral intake, nausea, and early satiety. These symptoms 
most likely secondary to essential thrombocythemia as well as 
compression from enlarged spleen. Patient received symptomatic 
management and supplements. Following initiation of Jackafi 
patient's symptoms gradually improved and patient tolerated PO 
well at discharge.

Thought to be secondary to vitamin K deficiency in setting of 
prolonged decreased oral intake. Patient received vitamin K. At 
discharge his INR is 1.3.

【19】Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted on ___ for abdominal exploration, repair, 
and reclosure of wound. Please follow these discharge 
instructions.
 .
Personal Care:
1. You may remove your dressings after 48 hours post surgery.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount.
 .
Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.
2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. ___.
 .
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered **DO NOT RESUME THE COUMADIN 
UNTIL DIRECTED TO BY ___. ___
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging.
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.
4. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
5. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish.
6. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
7. do not take any medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or 
Ibuprofen etc
 .
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
 .
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.
 .
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.

【20】WOUND VAC:
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.
 .
Personal Care:
1. You will have a wound VAC dressing with a wound vac machine 
in place for discharge home.  This dressing will be changed by 
the visiting nurse every three days or so when you return home.
2. While VAC is in place, please clean around the VAC site and 
monitor for air leaks of the VAC
3. A written record of the daily output from the VAC drain 
should be brought to every follow-up appointment. In addition, 
you should bring a VAC dressing kit to your follow up 
appointments with your doctor so that he/she may remove your VAC 
dressing, evaluate your wound and then apply fresh VAC dressing. 
 Your VAC drain will be removed as soon as possible and when it 
is determined that the wound is healthy enough to be surgically 
closed.
4. You may shower daily with assistance as needed. You should do 
this with wound vac apparatus disconnected from you. Once you 
have showered you will need to reconnect your dressing to the 
wound vac apparatus and make sure it is functioning properly.

【34】Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted 
to the Podiatric Surgery service after your R foot surgery. You 
were given IV antibiotics while here. You are being discharged 
home with the following instructions:  

【35】ACTIVITY:
There are restrictions on activity. Please remain non weight 
bearing to your right foot until your follow up appointment. You 
should keep this site elevated when ever possible (above the 
level of the heart!)
No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.

【36】PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS:
Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s).
New pain, numbness or discoloration of your foot or toes.
Watch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever 
greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus 
draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these 
or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR.

【37】Exercise:
Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks.
No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next ___ days.
Try to keep leg elevated when able.

【38】BATHING/SHOWERING:
You may shower immediately upon coming home, but you must keep 
your dressing CLEAN, DRY and INTACT. You can use a shower bag 
taped around your ankle/leg or hang your foot/leg outside of the 
bathtub.
Avoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for 4 
weeks after surgery or until cleared by your physician.

【39】MEDICATIONS:
Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the 
medications you were taking before surgery.
Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you 
should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check 
with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel 
that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may 
use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite 
suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small 
balanced meals throughout the day.

【40】DIET:
There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively. 
Poor appetite is not unusual for several weeks and small, 
frequent meals may be preferred.
FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
Be sure to keep your medical appointments.
If a follow up appointment was not made prior to your discharge, 
please call the office on the first working day after your 
discharge from the hospital to schedule a follow-up visit. This 
should be scheduled on the calendar for seven to fourteen days 
after discharge. Normal office hours are ___ 
through ___.

【41】PLEASE FEEL FREE TO CALL THE OFFICE WITH ANY OTHER CONCERNS OR 
QUESTIONS THAT MIGHT ARISE.
FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with your Podiatric Surgeon, Dr. ___. You 
will have follow up in the Podiatric Surgery Clinic in ___ days 
post-operation for evaluation. Call ___ in the event 
you are not contacted with your follow up appointment.
Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

【21】INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

【22】- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

【23】ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- NWB LLE in short cast

【24】MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

【25】ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Lovenox 40mg daily for 4 weeks

【26】WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Cast must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get Cast wet

【27】DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

stable in size s/p repair, without any evidence of endoleak. The 
patient's abdominal pain resolved gradually, and vascular 
surgery recommended maintenance of blood pressure < 140mmHg 
systolic. This required the patient to briefly be in the ICU for 
titration of esmolol and nicardipine, both of which were 
discontinued and the patient was transitioned to PO Labetalol at 
the time of being called out from the ICU. The patient's 
symptoms were monitored upon arrival to the floor and remained 
stable. She was started on an aggressive bowel regimen in the 
setting of constipation, as stool burden may have contributed to 
the patient's discomfort. Vascular surgery further recommended 
initiation of aspirin and statin, but the patient has a history 
of GI bleeding on aspirin, and has a history of CK elevation on 
Lipitor. As patient with multiple allergies, this was deferred 
at the time of discharge to outpatient providers for further 
evaluation and discussion with the patient. OF note, while 
abdominal pain was first described as sudden-onset, after 
further discussion with patient throughout hospitalization, it 
appears that abdominal pain may be more of a chronic issue. She 
was urged to continue to follow up with her providers regarding 
this.

【33】Medications
 Resume your normal medications and begin new medications as 
directed.
 You have been instructed by your doctor to take one aspirin a 
day. Do not take any other products that have aspirin in them. 
If you are unsure of what products contain aspirin, ask your 
pharmacist or call our office. 
 Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Plavix, 
Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
 You have been discharged on a medication called Nimodipine. 
This medication is used to help prevent cerebral vasospasm 
(narrowing of blood vessels in the brain). You will complete a 
total of 3 weeks of this medication.

you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

initiated until his rhythm native rhythm recovered. Lisinopril

toward the preoperative weight.  The patient was transferred to 
the telemetry floor for further recovery.  Chest tubes and 
pacing wires were discontinued without complication. He had a 
brief episode of afib but return to SR 60's.  The patient was 
evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with 
strength and mobility.  By the time of discharge on POD 5 the 
patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain 
was controlled with oral analgesics.  The patient was discharged 
to home in good condition with appropriate follow up 
instructions.

# Dyspnea: 

【20】Mr. ___ presented with worsening dyspnea and some chest pain 
on the evening of admission. The patient called EMS and was 
noted to be 93% on RA, tachypneic and using accessory muscles. 
They gave him a nebulizer and brought him to ___. In the ___, VS T 
97.2 HR 116 BP 117/79 RR 18 O2 Sat 96% on RA 2L. He was given 
albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers and azithromycin 500mg IV. 
On the floor, patient was not SOB at rest, but did complain of 
SOB on movement if not on 02 (e.g. with using the restroom 
without his 02). Given his history, medication non-compliance 
was suspected to be the most prominent contributing factor. He 
was restarted on Advair, tiotropium, and albuterol, which 
offered some relief. He was also thought to benefit from a short 
course of steroids, which were begun. However, his history of 
cough/nasal drainage was concerning for a COPD exacerbation 
triggered by bronchitis or URI, and the Azithromycin was 
continued. On ambulation with 02, patient's 02sat remained in 
the ___. However, 02 sat dropped to 84% without oxygen. Thus, it 
was felt it would necessary for him to received home 02; several 
members of the medical team including his PCP discussed the 
risks of fire/death with smoking + 02 with the patient.  He was 
discharged with instructions to continue Azithromycin 250 mg for 
3 more days (5 days total: 500 mg x1, 250 mgx4), continue 
prednisone: 40 mg 1 more day, 30 mg for 3 days, 20 mg for 3 
days; during this taper he will follow up with his PCP.  He will 
also continue dapsone for PCP prophylaxis for duration of 
steroid course.  He also was instructed to continue advair and 
tiotropium.  A home nebulizer was also arranged, and the patient 
will continue albuterol nebs 4 times a day.  Many members 
encouraged smoking cessation and emphasized the potential health 
benefits of cessation.  
# Chest pain: The patient noted an episode of chest pain on the 
evening of admission 'like a vice,' substernal without 
radiation, that came on while playing a computer game. It lasted 
15min, resolved spontaneously, and with no associated symptoms 
including SOB, N/V, dizziness, or palpitations.  In the 
hospital, 2 sets of cardiac enzymes were drawn, which were 
negative. No acute EKG changes were noted. Thus, acute coronary 
syndrome was thought to be unlikely. However, the patient had 
not had a stress test since ___, and given his difficulty with 
keeping prior appointments and cardiac risk factors, was ordered 
for a myocadial perfusion study (baseline EKG abnormalities 
precluded use of a stress test), which showed 1. Normal 
myocardial perfusion at the level of exercise achieved. 2. 
Normal left ventricular size and function with LVEF=58%. Thus, 
Aspirin was not continued. Again, smoking cessation was felt to 
be the best way to reduce cardiac risk.  As above, many members 
of the medical team including the residents and attending 
emphasized the health benefits of smoking cessation and offered 
assistance and resources.

Immunotyping : 
Cell marker analysis demonstrates a markedly lymphoid 
prodominant marrow sample, with marked T cell predominance. A 
majority of T-cells are a mixed population of CD4(+) and CD8(+) 
T-cells without major antigenic aberrancy. However, there is an 
expanded population of double negative T-cells (CD4-, CD8-) that 
comprise 7% of total CD3(+) T-lymphocytes. A major subset of 
these appear to express TCR-alpha-beta.
Since expansion of double-negative alpha-beta type T-cells can 
be seen in autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) 
correlation with clinical findings and possible molecular 
studies (e.g. FAS/FAS-mutational analysis) is suggested if 
clinically indicated.

lymphocytes which are predominantly small to medium in size as 
well as admixed erythroid and myeloid precursors and a small

account for the vast majority of the cellularity. In areas 
without lymphoid cells the cellularity is approximately ___.

while CD20 highlights only rare small scattered cells. CD4 and

alpha-beta. TCR gamma-delta expressing cells were scant . C-Kit D816V

consistent with a polyclonal T cell population. Molecular 
testing repeated through NeoGenomics revealed a clonal results 
by TCR gamma PCR only and a polyclonal result by TCR beta PCR 
and these results are of unclear significance. Cytogenetics

【43】In summary, the bone marrow aspirates and biopsy show a large 
population of T cells that are a mix of CD4 and CD8 positive

Dear Ms. ___, 

【71】You were admitted to ___ with fever, bruising and a cut that 
would not stop bleeding. We found that your white blood cells, 
red blood cells, and platelets were all low. As you know, we 
think this is due to a syndrome called autoimmune 
lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPs), in which some hyperactive 
immune cells suppress the production of other cells. We 
discussed your case with an expert in this syndrome at the ___. 
You were treated with high dose steroids (methylprednisolone and 
now prednisone), and another immunosuppressant medication called 
rapamycin. You were also given injections of neupogen to 
stimulate the production of white blood cells. All of your blood 
counts improved with this treatment. In addition to prednisone 
and rapamycin, you have a number of new medications to take, 
which protect you from viral, fungal, and bacterial infections. 

【72】You will follow up with Dr. ___ this week. He will

Findings: The visualized portions of intracranial structures are 
normal. The paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells are clear. 
Asymmetric soft tissue swelling with heterogeneous mixed-low 
attenuation pattern diffusely involves left parapharyngeal space 
from the level of of the medial pterygoids posterior to the 
maxillary sinus inferiorly to the level of the larynx and 
deformity and narrowing of the hypopharynx, and marked narrowing 
of the left piriform sinus. No discrete well circumscribed 
peripherally enhancing collection or abnormal soft tissue gas is 
seen; I suspect that much of this represents phlegmonous 
infectious process without discrete drainable collection yet 
present. Direct inspection and needle aspiration may be 
warranted, however. Extensive left anterior and posterior 
triangle lymphadenopathy with less pronounced reactive right 
anterior-posterior triangle lymphadenopathy.
The parotid and submandibular glands are symmetric and normal. 
The larynx, false and true cords, thyroid gland visualized 
portions of the superior mediastinum are normal. The vessels are 
well opacified and normal.
Conclusion: Extensive left parapharyngeal phlegmon as detailed 
with associated asymmetric lymphadenopathy. While no discrete 
well circumscribed collection is yet visible, I cannot exclude a 
developing parapharyngeal abscess within the extensive phlegmon, 
and direct visual inspection is recommended, and possible needle 
aspiration. No vascular compromise appreciated.

bowel movement.

urine, or experience a discharge.

within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
