【22】Discharge Instructions:
DO drink plenty of water to flush out the bladder. 
DO avoid straining during a bowel movement. Eat 
fiber-containing foods and avoid foods that can cause 
constipation. Ask your doctor if you should take a laxative if 
you do become constipated. 
Don't take blood-thinning medications until your doctor says 
it's OK. 
Don't do any strenuous activity, such as heavy lifting, for 
four to six weeks or until your doctor says it's OK. 
Don't have sex. You'll likely be able to resume sexual 
activity in about four to six weeks. 
Don't drive until your doctor says it's OK. ___, you can 
drive once your catheter is removed and you're no longer taking 
prescription pain medications. 

【23】You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve. You may 
have clear or yellow urine that periodically turns pink/red 
throughout the healing process. Generally, the discoloration of 
the urine is OK unless it transitions from ___, 
___ Aid to a very dark, thick or like tomato juice 
color

【24】Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. 
You should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any 
medication changes and your post-operative course with your 
primary care team.  

【25】Unless otherwise advised, blood thinning medications like 
ASPIRIN should be held until the urine has been clear/yellow for 
at least three days.  Your medication reconciliation will note 
if you may resume aspirin or prescription blood thinners (like 
Coumadin (warfarin), Xarelto, Lovenox, etc.)

【26】If needed, you will be prescribed an antibiotic to continue 
after discharge or save until your Foley catheter is removed 
(called a trial of void or void trial).  

【27】You may be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.

【28】Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative, and it is available 
over-the-counter 

【29】AVOID STRAINING for bowel movements as this may stir up 
bleeding.  Avoid  constipating foods for ___ weeks, and drink 
plenty of fluids to keep hydrated

【30】No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised

【31】Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
participate in high intensity physical activity (which includes 
intercourse) for a minimum of four weeks or until you are 
cleared by your Urologist in follow-up

【32】Acetaminophen (Tylenol) should be your first-line pain 
medication. A narcotic pain medication may also be prescribed 
for breakthrough or moderate pain.  

【33】The maximum daily Tylenol/Acetaminophen dose is 3 grams from 
ALL sources. 

【34】Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do 
not operate dangerous machinery.  

【35】WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:
o-Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on 
routine care and hygiene

【36】o-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your

【37】o-DO NOT allow anyone outside your urologist/team 
representative remove your Foley for any reason.

【38】o-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time. The leg bag (if 
provided)  is for short-duration periods and the bag must be 
emptied frequently.

【39】o-Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your 
safety-but of course you may be a passenger

【15】Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ arrived to the Emergency Departemnt at ___ 
___ on ___ with loss of DP pulse on the 
left side as well as new onset calf pain and coolness in the 
foot. Ultrasonography of Left leg was performed revealing 
occlusion of her bypass graft. A left lower extremity 
angiography was offered and the patient was admitted to the 
Vascular Surgery service. Patient was consented.

【16】On ___ the patient went to the OR and underwent a Left lower 
extremity angiogram and Right groin lysis catheter to the Left 
lower extremity. There was found to be an occlusion of the left 
femoral-to-popliteal bypass graft and placement of lysis 
catheter, which was a 50 cm ___ catheter within the 
distal vein graft was performed. For more details of the 
procedure, please see the surgeon's operative note. The patient 
tolerated the procedure well. Following the proceudure she had 
two episodes of groin oozing/bleeding which were controlled with 
pressure over the wound. She was brought to the post-anesthesia 
care unit in stable condition. The patient received TPA via drip 
into her graft overnight.

【17】On ___, the patient was taken back to the angiosuite for 
lysis check and possible definitive intervention. The risks, 
benefits and alternatives to this
course of treatment were explained to the patient in detail and 
she consented to proceed. An AngioJet thrombectomy of the left 
femoral to above-knee popliteal bypass graft performed as well 
as percutaneous transluminal angioplasty and stenting of 
existing graft and the below-knee popliteal artery into the 
anterior tibial artery. 20 minutes of manual pressure were held 
to the right groin with excellent hemostasis and the procedure 
was terminated without complications. The patient was then 
observed with serial examination until return of her 
pre-sedation mental status and
then taken to the surgical floor for further recovery.

【18】Following procedure the patient had Left palpable DP. No 
evidence of bleeding. Heparin gtt was continued and planned for 
Pradaxa (given Coumadin failure) when groin stabilized. That 
same day patient started oozing from entry site in Right groin. 
Pressure was held for a considerable amount of time without much 
improvement and a suture was placed. Oozing was controlled. Hct 
was persistently in the 23 range and 1 unit of PRBC was given 
due to the restrictive transfusion threshold from her LBBB. Post 
transfusion Hct was 24.

【19】On ___, Left DP pulse was still appreciated. Foley 
catheter was removed, patient voided, and got out of bed to the 
chair. A pre-authorization for Pradaxa medication was requested. 
Physical Therapy worked with the patient who was well below 
baseline and recommended rehabilitation.

【20】On ___, Hct dropped to 21.9, second check demonstrated a 
Hct of 21.8. A unit of PRBC was administered with a 
post-transfusion Hct of 23.7 & 23.9. Pre-authorization for

【21】At this point the patient was clear from the Vascular standpoint 
and was ready to being discharged but anticoagulation plan 
remained pending.

【22】On ___, Xarelto was denied. Apixaban was screened and 
approved. Suture at groin site was removed. Apixaban was 
administered the day prior to discharge.

【23】Today, ___, the patient is stable, tolerating regular diet, 
getting out of bed with assistance, voiding without issues, and 
pain is adequately controlled. No evidence of bleeding or 
hematoma at groin site. The patient was deemed ready for 
discharge, and was given the appropriate discharge and follow-up 
instructions.

【31】You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent lysis and stenting of your occluded graft. You have

【32】WHAT TO EXPECT:
 1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
 2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
 3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite 
will return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

【33】MEDICATION:

 An anticoagulant (Apixaban) will be started, please take it as 
instructed.
 Follow your discharge medication instructions

【34】ACTIVITIES:

pain medications
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

【35】 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
 You should gradually increase your activity
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed

【36】CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Redness that extends away from your incision
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

【20】Discharge Instructions:
Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Carotid Endarterectomy Surgery Discharge Instructions

【21】What to expect when you go home:
1. Surgical Incision:
It is normal to have some swelling and feel a firm ridge along 
the incision
Your incision may be slightly red and raised, it may feel 
irritated from the staples

【22】2. You may have a sore throat and/or mild hoarseness
Try warm tea, throat lozenges or cool/cold beverages 

【23】3. You may have a mild headache, especially on the side of your 
surgery
Try ibuprofen, acetaminophen, or your discharge pain 
medication
If headache worsens, is associated with visual changes or 
lasts longer than 2 hours- call vascular surgeons office

【24】4. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
You may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

【25】5. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

【26】What activities you can and cannot do:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
No excessive head turning, lifting, pushing or pulling 
(greater than 5 lbs) until your post op visit
You may shower (no direct spray on incision, let the soapy 
water run over incision, rinse and pat dry)
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed
Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, 
unless otherwise directed 
Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 2 weeks for 
staple/suture removal

【27】What to report to office:
Changes in vision (loss of vision, blurring, double vision, 
half vision)
Slurring of speech or difficulty finding correct words to use
Severe headache or worsening headache not controlled by pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your arm or leg 
or the ability to feel your arm or leg
Trouble swallowing, breathing, or talking
Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

【18】1. Septic shock: Patient admitted with septic shock secondary to 
polymicrobial bactermia with liver abscess.  She underwent 
initial early goal directed therapy with 4L IV fluid, right IJ 
placement with initiation of levophed, and broad spectrum 
antibiotics with Vanc/Zosyn. CT abdomen/pelvis was done, showing 
an abscess amenable for U/S-guided drainage. ___ placed 
transcutaneous transhepatic catheter with drainage of purulent 
fluid.  The CT scan did not show any diverticulitis or other 
potential source for bacteremia. Despite some mild gall bladder 
thickening, the surgery team did not feel that there was 
cholecystitis. CEA and alpha-fetoprotein were normal.  TTE 
showed no evidence of endocarditis as source of infection. 
Following drain placement, septic physiology resolved and 
patient was able to wean off pressors.  Patient became afebrile, 
leukocytosis resolved and LFTs slowly normalized.  Purulent 
fluid from liver abscess grew fusobacterium and blood cultures 
returned with strep anginosus and fusobacterium.  Vancomycin/ 
zosyn was tailored to zosyn and then to ertapenem on discharge. 
Picc line was placed once patient was afebrile for > 24 hrs and 
blood cultures were negative.  

【19】Patient will need 4 weeks of ertapenem ___ - ___ 
with weekly monitoring of CBC, BMP and LFTs.  She will need a CT 
scan in 3 weeks to ensure resolution of abscess prior to 
discontinuation of antibiotics/ drain.  She will need to have 
transhepatic drain in place until follow up with surgery in 
approximately 6 weeks.  In addition, an ongoing investigation is 
recommended for source of initial infection, in particular she 
will need full dental evaluation.   

【20】2. Tachypnea: on admission, patient was noted to be tachypneic, 
and had intermittent wheezing and respiratory distress through 
ICU stay. On ___ she required non-invasive positive-pressure 
ventilation in the setting of severe tachypnea.  Respiratory 
distress was felt to be multifactorial from reactive airways 
disease (despire no hisotory of asthma/ COPD), atelectasis from 
shallow breathing and b/l pleural effusions in the setting of 
volume resuscitation and sepsis.
On ___, she was started on solumedrol for empiric treatment of 
reactive airway disease which was changed to inhaled steriod on 
___ as there was no improvement in symptoms. On ___ she had 
a lung CT which showed bilateral effusions and airspace disease 
from likely atelectasis.  She was diuresed gently given acute 
kidney injury and respiratory status improved.  By time of 
discharge, patient was breathing comfortably on room air. 

【21】3.  Rash: On ___ patient was noted to have an erythematous 
puritic rash on her back.  Dermatology was consulted and thought 
that the rash represented miliaria in the setting of prolonged 
bedrest although a localized allergic reaction could not be 
excluded.  Patient was treated conservatively with triamcinolone 
cream and sarna lotion prn with significant improvement in 
symptoms.  Of note, during this time zosyn was also changed to 
ertapenem.  It is unlikely that the change in antibiotics 
resulted in improvement in rash as there were no systemic signs 
of an allergic reaction.

【22】4. Acute kidney injury: In the setting of severe septic shock, 
patient did have limited acute kidney injury with creatinine 
rising from baseline of 0.9 - 1 to 1.3.  Resolved with 
supportive care and avoidence of nephrotoxins.

【43】Discharge Instructions:
Surgery
You underwent a biopsy. A sample of tissue from the lesion in 
your brain was sent to pathology for testing. 
You may shower at this time but keep your incision dry.
It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

【44】Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

【45】Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

【46】What You ___ Experience:
You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

【47】When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

【48】Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

Impression:
The scout film revealed CCY clips.

ducts. Contrast extended to the entire biliary tree.

were normal.

sphincterotomy was made with a sphincterotome. There was no 
post-sphincterotomy bleeding.

bifurcation.
Sludge was removed.

was seen.
The final occlusion cholangiogram showed no evidence of filling 
defects in the CBD.
Excellent bile and contrast drainage was seen endoscopically and 
fluoroscopically.
The pancreatic duct was partially filled with contrast and 
visualized only proximally. This appeared normal.

citalopram as acceptable Class C agents.  Citalopram 10mg was 
started on this admission for anxiety. and she responded well.

pregnancy clinic given her history of seizures and prior 
miscarriages.   We discharged her on her home dose of trileptal

【45】Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions

【46】What to expect when you go home:

【47】1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

【48】2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated

【49】3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

【50】What activities you can and cannot do:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

【51】You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
You should gradually increase your activity
You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed
Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, 
unless otherwise directed 
Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 2 weeks for 
staple/suture removal

【52】What to report to office:
Redness that extends away from your incision
A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

<120. The patient was transitioned to PO blood pressure

stay off of esmolol gtt. He was transferred out of the ICU to a 
VICU bed where his blood pressure continued to be monitored. His 
final regimen was carvedilol and lisinopril, and his blood 
pressures remained at goal <120s systolic. He had transient back 
pain on ___ which self resolved and was not felt to be related 
to his dissection. Physical therapy evaluated the patient and 
recommended home with ___ and cardiac rehab. Home ___ services 
were arranged and the patient was advised to follow up with his 
outpatient cardiologist for a cardiac rehab referral. Of note, 
during the course of the admission on ___, the vascular 
medicine team adjusted his PPM to 55, with the following note: 
"He has managed ventricular pacing on to enhance intrinsic 
ventricular function, so he will occasionally show atrial paced 
beats that do not conduct a ventricular beat which will then 
trigger the PPM to more aggressively pace. The PPM is 
functioning normally. He has some atrial high rate events, but 
it is hard to say if these are definitely AF. Will defer to 
outpatient provider, who is aware of mode switching." By the day 
of admission the patient's blood pressures were well controlled, 
he was asymptomatic and feeling well, was tolerating diet and 
his PO antihypertensive regimen. He was deemed ready for 
discharge home with visiting nurse assistance for blood pressure 
checks, home ___, and PO antihypertensive agents, with plan for 
outpatient follow up with repeat CTA in 3 months.

【15】Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with HIV, Kaposi's Sarcoma, 
and Primary Effusion Lymphoma who presented for the next cycle 
of chemotherapy for Kaposi's Sarcoma with Taxol given the 
shortage of Doxil. While in house, the patient began to worsen 
with more anasarca of the lower extremities, scrotum, and lower 
abdominal wall. A decision was made by the primary oncology team 
to pursue a different chemotherapy route using EPOCH. This 
regimen lasted ___. Results were promising as the KS 
rash began to dissipate, but the swelling continued to worsen or 
at least stay the same. Lasix was pushed IV to attempt to clear 
some of the excess fluid which the chemo brought on, this worked 
minimally. The patient was continued on his HAART regimen the 
entire hospital course as well as Azithromycin, Bactrim, 
Fluconazole, and Gancyclovir for prophylaxis with changes in 
dose and frequency daily based on weight and renal function. The 
largest problem for the patient this admission was pain control. 
Mostly caused by the edema, the patient was finally stabilized 
on a PO Oxycontin and PO Dilaudid regimen for long-acting and 
short-acting breakthrough pain control respectively. Towards the 
last few before discharge, ___ wanted to leave more and more. 
Despite warnings against leaving while his white count was 
___ decided it was time for him to leave. He was 
profoundly neutropenic, developing a sore throat, productive 
cough, worsening right-sided pleural edema, and shortness of 
breath the day he left. We educated him on neutropenic 
precautions, gave him Neupogen for home and orders to come back 
if he can't find it, and the appropriate PPX and treatment 
medications. He had follow-up the week following with multiple 
departments.

【27】Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
It was a pleasure to take care of you during this admission. You 
were admitted due to your increased pain and swelling from your 
Kaposi's sarcoma. With Lasix, the water pill, and steroids the 
swelling improved over the course of your stay. We also worked 
with pain management to find a pain regimen that worked for you.
When you arrived you received one dose of Taxol for your 
disease. However since your disease was still progressing, a 
decision was made to start you on aggressive chemotherapy called 
EPOCH. This therapy dropped your blood counts tremendously. You 
are now neutropenic, meaning that your white blood cells are 
below the level at which they protect you from normal everyday 
infections. You must take precautions to keep yourself safe from 
infection until your counts rise. A medication called Neupogen 
will be delivered to your house today. If you do not get this 
package, YOU MUST COME BACK TOMORROW ___ at NOON) TO THE 
___, ___ FLOOR. You will need to take this medication 
daily. 
.
Towards the last 3 days of your stay here, you developed a sore 
throat, cough, some shortness of breath, and signs on chest 
x-ray suspicious for an organizing pneumonia. We started you on 
an antibiotic called Ciprofloxacin in addition to the 
prophylactic antibiotics you already take. If these symptoms 
worsen, please do not hesitate to call your doctor or come back 
to the hospital. If you start to have a fever, you should return 
to the hospital right away.
Your current medication regimen is listed in the chart that was 
explained to you on discharge. Please take/use only the 
medications listed on this new printout. This should help to 
streamline your medication regimen. You will no longer receive 
IV medication, but the PICC will remain until you pass the oral 
trial of the valgancyclovir. 
.
It is vital to your health that you attend all of the 
appointments listed below. When attending these appointments, 
please wear the masks that we are sending you home with in order 
to protect you from the germs in the ___ environment.
If you have any questions about what is safe for you to do on a 
daily basis, please call the doctor's office and/or refer to the 
sheet on neutropenic precautions given to you at discharge.
We wish you the best of luck in your recovery. Take care of 
yourself.

【26】Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the 
Operating Room where she underwent a laparoscopic repair of 
hiatal hernia and a Toupet fundoplication. She tolerated the 
procedure well and returned to the PACU in stable condition. She 
maintained stable hemodynamics and her pain was controlled with 
Tylenol and oral Oxycodone.  She tolerated sips of water without 
difficulty.

【27】Following transfer to the Surgical floor she progressed well.  
She began a soft diet on post op day #1 which was well 
tolerated. Her port sites were healing well and her oxygen was 
weaned off with room air saturations of 95%.  She was using her 
incentive spirometer effectively. Her pre op medications were 
resumed including prednisone, cyclosporine and Coumadin will 
begin this evening at her home dose of 6.25 mg.  She continues 
to have adequate pain relief with Tylenol and Oxycodone but 
refused a stool softener as she's prone to diarrhea.

【21】Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a PMHx significant 
for hepatitis C cirrhosis s/p liver transplant in ___, 
recurrent cirrhosis and portal hypertension s/p TIPS in ___, 
and s/p Hep C treatment and sustained viralogic response who 
presented to the ER ___ with left sided chest pressure and pain 
that radiated to the arm as well as diffuse abdominal pain. 

【22】These symptoms had been present without remission for a few 
days. She also described chills, diffuse fatigue, depression, 
anhedonia, and low energy. She denied trauma to the chest wall. 
In the ER she had CT abdomen-pelvis that showed no cause of her 
symptoms. A CXR was normal. EKG and troponins x2 were not 
indicative of acute coronary syndrome. She was admitted for 
inpatient stress testing. 

【23】Given the nature of her exam, which included tenderness over the 
entire chest wall and entire abdomen, and her historical 
description of chest pain that had been present for days without 
change, we felt that this was highly unlikely to be anginal. She 
requested oxycodone repeatedly and we thought that she did not 
have a clear indication. Her pain may have been due to 
musculoskeletal strain of the intercostal muscles, but this 
would not explain her diffuse abdominal pain without imaging 
correlate. She has a history of recent discontinuation of her 
buprenorphine opiate abstinence therapy due to high insurance 
copay. 

【24】Overall, we felt that angina was unlikely and that she could 
have an outpatient stress test safely. We also recommended to 
her that she seek psychiatric therapy for depression treatment, 
which appeared to be a major background complaint. She would 
also benefit from alternative opiate abstinence therapy if there 
are more cost effective options, such as naltrexone.

【26】Brief Hospital Course:
In brief, this is a ___ year-old man with history of 
hypertension, repaired thoracic aortic dissection with residual 
abdominal aortic dissection, prior atrial fibrillation and 
flutter, and obesity who presents with dyspnea and palpitations.

【27】# Shortness of breath: The most likely etiology for his symptoms 
was the recurrence of atrial fibrillation and flutter. 
Initially, his dyspnea was very concerning for pulmonary emboli, 
in setting of recent immobility and elevated D-dimer. He 
underwent iodinated-contrast pretreatment prednisone and 
Benadryl, and a CTA chest was negative for pulmonary embolus. 
Bilateral LENIs were negative for DVT. With these in mind, VTE 
was excluded. Alternative but unlikely etiologies were pulmonary 
infection (has cough but not productive and no fever or 
leukocytosis), acute coronary syndrome (lesss likely in the 
absence of chest pain, and biomarkers remained negative) or 
aortic dissection/aneurysm (back pain, but aorta radiologically 
stable on CTA).

【28】# Atrial arrhythmia: In the past, his atrial arrhythmias were 
precipitated by his cardiac surgery. On this occasion, it is 
unclear what was the precipitant. His TSH was within normal 
limits. Per patient, he had been in normal sinus since flutter 
ablation in ___. ECGs in our system did not contradict this.  
He underwent repeat atrial flutter ablation after a 
transesophageal echocardiogram showed no atrial clot and 
remained in NSR subsequently. We discussed with vascular surgery 
regarding the risks of anticoagulation, and the decision was 
made to start him on warfarin with heparin/enoxoparin bridge. We 
recommend long term anticoagulation given a CHADS score of 3, 
unless otherwise indicated given his abdominal vascular disease. 
His dual beta-blocker regimen was simplified to metoprolol 
succinate only.

【29】# Anomalous coronary arteries: His coronary CTA from ___ 
was reviewed and his case discussed amongst the cardiac surgeons 
and interventional cardiologists. The patient reported no 
limitations to physical activity, exercising ___ times weekly 
for 50 minutes on a treadmill at ___ mph with estimated heart 
rate 115-123 bpm, all without chest pain or dyspnea. He did 
report profound diaphoresis after hiking for 30 minutes, 
especially with inclines. Although autopsy studies have 
suggested an increase prevalence of interarterial coronary 
artery anomalies (where a major vessel runs between the 
pulmonary artery and aorta) amongst individuals who die 
suddenly, the exact increase in risk cannot be quantitated as 
the denominator at risk is unknown. As Mr. ___ has survived 
with his coronary artery anomaly (only the LAD proper runs 
between the PA and aorta; the anomalous circumflex runs 
posteriorly, and the LMCA 通用删除8(英):<u>[not seen on coronary angiography]</u> 
supplies a diagonal and a ramus branch), the risks of 
prophylactic surgical revascularization (with increased risk of 
graft attrition absent any high-grade flow-limiting stenoses) 
were not felt to outweigh the theoretical benefits. Mr. 
___ abnormal coronary artery anatomy was reviewed with 
him and the above risk-benefit analysis discussed. It was 
suggested that he not exercise or hike alone. An outpatient 
nuclear perfusion exercise stress test was ordered to assess for 
objective evidence of ischemia. He was continued on ASA for 
secondary prevention, and his statin was changed from lovastatin 
40 mg daily to atorvastatin 40 mg daily for formulary reasons 
and to achieve a lower LDL to minimize progression of CAD given 
his aberrant anatomy and perhaps higher sheer stress on the LAD.

【18】Postoperative course:

【19】Neuro: His mental status remained unchanged throughout his 
hospitalization. The Acute Pain Service was consulted for 
___ pain management and a thoracic epidural was placed. The 
epidural was titrated to effect and discontinued on postop day 
#1 and removed on ___ day #2. IV analgesics were also 
administered prn. The patient was started on PCA on ___ day 
#1 prior to removal of the epidural until, which he reported to 
provide adequate pain control. He remained on PCA until ___ 
day #11, when it was discontinued and he was administered IV 
analgesics as needed thereafter, which were eventually changed 
to liquid oxycodone given via the dobhoff. By the day of 
discharge on ___, he denied any pain and was not requiring 
any narcotic pain medication.

【20】Card: His vital signs were monitored routinely postoperatively. 
On postop day#1 he was triggered for hypotension with a systolic 
BP in the 70's and his epidural was stopped. During this episode 
there were no signs if inadequate blood flow, and his blood 
pressure quickly recovered to within normal limits after 
stopping the epidural and with the administration of a liter 
fluid bolus. Aside from this one episode of hypotension, he 
remained hemodynamically stable in his postoperative course.

【21】Pulm: Pulmonary toileting and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged. His oxygen saturation was checked with vitals and 
remained within normal limits.

【22】GI: During the operation, Dobbhoff feeding tube was passed 
through the stomach and placed through the Roux limb to below 
the jejunojejunostomy. Initially postoperatively Mr. ___ 
remained NPO with IV fluids for hydration. On ___ day #3 he 
was started on tube feeds via the dobbhoff. On ___ day #5, 
he was started on clear liquids and his tube feeds were advanced 
to goal. However, on postop day #6, he became nauseated and 
vomited, and his tube feeds were slowed down. A KUB was 
concerning for an ileus, and he was started on reglan in an 
attempt to speed up gastric emptying.  On postop day #7, a CT 
ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST was obtained because the patient was 
continually nauseated with hiccups and continuing leukocytosis, 
which also indicated ileus/possible obstruction, but no 
intra-abdominal or intrapelvic abscess was detected. He was 
started on erythromycin in addition to reglan in an attempt to 
speed up his gastric emptying. On postop day #8, an NG tube was 
placed to suction and tubefeedings were discontinued. The next 
day on postop day #9, a PICC was placed in his left arm and he 
was started on TPN. On postop day #11 he was started on 
thorazine for hiccups, which discontinued the following day on 
postop day #12 do the poor tolerance/sedative side effects. On 
postop day #12 a small bowel study with gastrografin was 
performed which showed no evidence of stricture or obstruction 
within the bowel surrounding the jejunojejunal anastomosis. 
Tubefeeds were restarted via the dobbhoff at this time. However, 
that evening the dobbhoff tube accidentally fell out while the 
patient was getting up to the commode. The next day on postop 
day #13, the patient was restarted on sips of clear liquids and 
the dobbhoff was replaced at bedside and advanced in 
interventional radiology past the gastrojejunal anastamosis. 
Again tubefeeds were restarted and slowly advanced to goal by 
postop day #14 and he was started on a clear liquid diet, which 
he tolerated with no further emesis, and therefore, TPN was 
discontinued at this time. On postop day #15 he was advanced to 
a full liquid diet. However, he repeatedly became nauseated with 
multiple episodes of emesis on this diet.  On ___ an abdominal 
CT showed a complete resolution of small bowel dilation and 
fecalization seen on ___ exam. His tube feeds were 
continued at goal. At the time of discharge on ___, he was 
tolerating tube feeds at goal at 50 cc/h via the dobhoff and 
remained NPO, with his most recent KUB on ___ showing no 
evidence of obstruction. He was discharged with a scheduled 
upper GI barium swallow study on ___, and further follow up 
in ___ clinic on ___.

【23】GU: A foley catheter was placed during the operation, which 
remained in place for urine output monitoring until postop day 
#4, when it was removed. He voided for the remained of the 
hospitalization without need for any further catheterization. On 
postop day #7, his WBC continued to increase and a u/a and 
culture were sent which came back positive with a the culture 
showing KLEBSIELLA PNEUMONIAE >100,000 ORGANISMS/ML. For this he 
was started on a 7 day course of IV ciprofloxacin which was 
completed on ___.

【24】Musk: A physical therapy consult was obtained postoperatively to 
evaluate his mobility. He was encouraged to mobilize out of bed 
and ambulate as tolerated throughout his postoperative course. 
By discharge he was ambulating independently without assistance.

【25】Heme/ID: See GU section for UTI. His electrolytes were monitored 
and repleted as needed throughout his hospitalization. His WBC 
count was trended to monitor for signs of infection. This 
leukocytosis at 14.9 on postop day #7 and was down to within 
normal limits at 10.7 on postop day #14. At this time he 
remained afebrile and without any further signs of infection. 
However on ___, his WBC count again climbed to 17.4. He 
remained afebrile without any signs of infection at this time. A 
CT scan of his abd/pelvis was performed at this time which 
showed no evidence of intra-abdominal abscess formation. Blood 
and urine cultures were also obtained at this time. Urine 
culture grew out ENTEROCOCCUS SP 10,000-100,000 ORGANISMS/ML, 
however, his urine was clear, he remained afebrile, and the 
patient denied any urinary symptoms. His blood cultures are 
still pending to this date. However, his leukocytosis quickly 
resolved without intervention, with his most recent WBC count at 
7.8 on ___. At the time of discharge on ___, he remains 
afebrile and without any signs of infection.

You were admitted to the hospital after undergoing a partial 
gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y reconstruction.

【35】Please call the ___ clinic or return to the Emergency Department 
for any of the following:

【36】*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

【37】*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

【38】*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

【39】*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

【40】*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.

【41】*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.

【42】*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

【43】*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

【44】Continue your tube feeds as instructed by the visiting nurses. 

【45】You can take an over-the-counter stool softener such as colace 
(ducosate sodium) if needed for constipation. This medication 
can be given in liquid form through your feeding tube if needed.
You may also take liquid tylenol through your feeding tube if 
needed for pain. Do not exceed greater than 4 gm of tylenol in 
24 hours.

【46】Please get plenty of rest and continue to ambulate several times 
per day. Avoid lifting weights greater than 25 lbs until you 
follow-up with your surgeon.

【47】Incision Care:

【48】*Please call the clinic if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision site.

【49】*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.

【50】*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.

【51】*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

Dear Mr. ___,

【57】You were hospitalized due to symptoms of left-sided numbness 
resulting from an ACUTE HEMORRHAGIC STROKE, also known as a 
brain bleed. The brain is the part of your body that controls 
and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the 
brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a 
variety of symptoms.

【58】Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:
- Diabetes 
- High blood pressure 

【59】We are changing your medications as follows:

【62】Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician

【63】If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you

PROTEIN 17 GLUCOSE ___ year old female with a history of breast cancer, asthma and 
progressive muscle weakness previously diagnosed as motor 
predominant CIDP who presented with worsening shortness of 
breath in the setting of a recent flu-like illness for one week: 

【51】#respiratory failure likely secondary to neuromuscular weakness
#progressive weakness
#presumed motor neuron disease
She reported a flu-like illness for one week and then one day of 
shortness of breath. She was intubated on admission due to 
respiratory distress. Given the acuity of her respiratory 
failure and history of progressive muscle weakness, there was a 
re-evaluation of her prior diagnosis of motor predominant CIDP. 
EMG was performed, showing ongoing denervation and 
re-innervation of her muscles, possibly consistent with motor 
neuron disease such as ALS. However, her exam was notable for 
LMN signs (fasciculations, no increased tone, generalized 
atrophy, absent reflexes in the lower extremities) but no UMN 
signs. Given this, her prior diagnosis of CIDP was called into 
question. Family meeting was held to discuss the new diagnosis 
and the family and patient decided to move towards a trach/peg 
which were done on ___.

【52】Given that her exam findings of symmetric and distal>proximal 
weakness with other lower motor neuron findings and long 
progressive course of her weakness in conjuction with EMG 
findings suggests a possible motor neuron disease (with PMA 
being more likely rather than ALS given LMN; or potentially a 
later onset SMA) vs. myopathy (however, would expect a more 
proximal weakness) such as inclusion body myositis (which can be 
distal and proximal weakness; however, fasciculations being 
present would argue against this as well as normal CK) or a 
muscular dystrophy variant (however, normal CK) vs. motor 
neuropathy such as hereditary motor neuropathy or immune 
mediated motor neuropathy. 

【53】Notably, she does have possible family history of progressive 
weakness in her mother and one of her maternal aunts; however, 
they lived into their ___ but seemed to have weakness (one aunt 
always was sitting and her mother seemed to "furniture walk" and 
had trouble with stairs). However, there was no formal diagnosis 
of a neurologic/muscular disease process. She also has family 
history of cancer (breast cancer in patient, overian cancer in 
sister, lung cancer in brother).

【54】For additional work-up of her progressive weakness, CT torso was 
done which did not show evidence of underlying maligancy. LP was 
attempted to see if inflammatory cells were present in CSF which 
would be more consistent with CIDP; however, given her anatomy, 
this was not possible at the bedside. LP was performed by ___

at the time of discharge. Cytosolic 5' nucleotidase (sporadic

#LLE
Admitted post-operatively after having a hardware removal, I&D 
of ST & bone of the left foot.  Large amounts of sanguinous 
fluid was expressed from the posterior ankle .  Post-op xrays showed osseous destruction, 
disorganization, and debris involving the rearfoot and midfoot.

【28】General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.

prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 
weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* use an abdominal binder
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

【29】Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.
* If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
visit.

【17】# Sepsis: On admission patient had leukocytosis, fever and 
tachycardia with foot ulcer as most likely source, meeting 
criteria for sepsis. He received IV fluids, vancomycin and zosyn 
(day ___, blood cultures were sent. His heart rate rapidly 
improved and fever did not recur. Further ulcer management as 
below.

【18】# Left foot ulcer: Clinical picture consistent with sepsis from 
foot ulcer, likely from arterial insufficiency, with 
uncontrolled diabetes contributing to poor healing. 
Leukocytosis, fevers, elevated ESR and CRP all concerning for 
osteomyelitis, plain films of the foot did not show evidence of 
this, but not sensistive or specific. He was treated with 
vancomycin and zosyn (day ___ and changed to vancomycin and 
meropenem on ___ secondary to concern that the foot ulcer 
appeared clinically worse.  While here he underwent a left 
common iliac artery stent and EIA stent and SFA stent.  Then, an 
I&D of the L heel ulcer was performed.  He recovered from this 
procedure well

【19】# Peripheral arterial disease: Risk factors include 
hypertension, smoking, age, DM. Lipids LDL 72, HDL 38. ABIs 
consistent with significant disease L>R. CT also showed 
significant bilateral atherosclerosis. He was started on aspirin 
and a statin, vascular surgery was consulted. He was taken to 
the OR on ___ and 1. Ultrasound-guided vascular access of

aortogram. 7. Left lower extremity angiogram. 8. Perclose 
closure of the right common femoral artery, was performed, which 
went well without complication (please refer to operative note 
for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the 
patient arrived back on the floor. His diet was advanced when

【23】Brief Hospital Course:
#.Chest pain: patient's pain was concerning for ACS given the 
history, however troponins  were only mildly elevated, CK-MBs 
were within normal limits and code STEMI was cancelled after 
cardiology review of EKGs read  as early repolarization. The 
chest X-ray taken appeared rotated, but there was some concern 
for widened mediastinum.  This raised a question of a possible 
aortic dissection, however the character of pain was not typical 
of dissection.  Systolic blood pressure difference was <20 
manually, with minimal pulse difference, which made aortic 
dissection a bit less likely. Presentation was less concerning 
for pulmonary embolus, given that there was a normal d-dimer and 
no respiratory symptoms, and patient was not tachycardic. There 
was no evidence of pneumonia on chest X-ray.  The pain the 
patient experienced was reproducible on palpation, suggesting a 
possible musculoskeletal etiology.  Possible etiologies of the 
pain after workup included stable angina, unstable angina and 
musculoskeletal pain.   Cardiac biomarkers were only mildly 
elevated.  She was determined not to require catheterization or 
stress test during hospitalization.  Patient was continued on 
home dose of statin, beta blocker, ACE inhibitor, and aspirin.  
Patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with her 
primary care provider.
#.Hypertension: patient was continued on home dose of metoprolol 
and lisinopril.
#.Heart murmur: patient had a ___ systolic ejection murmur on 
presentation.  Patient could not recall if this was present 
previously.  An echocardiogram was performed and showed no gross 
abnormalities.
#.Bipolar disorder: patient was continued on home dose of 
Depakote during admission.
#.Osteoarthritis: patient was continued on home regimen of 
naproxen, tylenol and tramadol.
#.GERD: patient was continued on home dose of omeprazole.

transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable condition. On

urethral Foley catheter were removed without difficulty and diet 
was advanced as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course 
was unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable 
condition, eating well, ambulating independently, voiding 
without difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On 
exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of 
hematoma collection or infection. The patient was given explicit 
instructions to follow-up in clinic in four weeks.

【23】-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision

momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.

【24】--There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have

strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
get the steristrips wet.

【25】-UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED; AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing 
products and supplements that may have blood-thinning effects 
(like Fish Oil, Vitamin E, etc.).  This will be noted in your 
medication reconciliation. 

【26】IF PRESCRIBED :
-IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken 
even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You 
may alternate these medications for pain control.  

【27】For pain control, try TYLENOL (acetaminophen) FIRST, then 
ibuprofen, and then take the narcotic pain medication as 
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.

【28】-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue 
taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your 
stool (dark, tarry stools)

【29】-Call your Urologist's office to schedule/confirm your follow-up 
appointment in 4 weeks AND if you have any questions.

【30】-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

【31】-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
couch potato

【32】-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___.

【33】-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams 
from ALL sources

【34】AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 
3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high 
intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until 
you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up.

【35】-No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your 
Urologist

【36】-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
bathe

【37】-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

【38】-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener and/or a 
gentle laxative. These are  over-the-counter medications that 
may be health care spending account reimbursable. 

【39】-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid 
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

【40】-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to 
further minimize your risk of constipation. 

【41】-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

including monitoring her abdominal compartment pressures for the 
development of abdominal compartment syndrome and stabilizing 
respiratory status. After she was extubated and transferred to 
the floor, the patient was discovered to have bilataral PEs and 
was bridged to coumadin therapy and she also had a leukocytosis 
secondary to a respiratory process.

【15】In further detail, by pertinent system:

【16】Respiratory:
Her ventilator settings went from PEEP/PS ___ to ___ in 
response to continued worsening of respiratory status.  Patient 
showed signs of fluid under-resuscitation and received multiple 
boluses of albumin in addition to crystalloid.

【17】On POD 1 and 2, patient remained intubated and effort to wean 
respirator from 80% FiO2 was unfruitful. Her respiratory status 
was concerning for atelectasis vs. PE.  Lower extremity dopplers 
did not show evidence of DVTs.  

【18】Ventilator wean attempt was made again and this time successful, 
decreasing FiO2 to 60%, then 50%.  By POD 4, she was 
transitioned to CPAP, paralytics stopped and sedation minimized 
and by POD 5, she was extubated.  Also on POD 5, she was started 
on TPN to bridge nutritional status until the return of bowel 
function and diet.

【19】On POD 6, with stable respiratory status, she was transferred to 
the floor, on TPN and NPO.  Patient was OOB and ambulating but 
during her first night on the floor, she complained of mild 
shortness of breath which gradually improved through the morning 
of POD 7.  She also had two small bowel movements and her diet 
was advanced to sips of clears.  

【20】On POD 8, patient showed worsening leukocytosis, now at 14.3 
(from 12 on POD 7 and 10.3 on POD 6) but had no more complaints 
of shortness of breath.  UA, UCx, CXR ordered (all negative for 
infectious process) and the foley catheter was removed. 

【21】On POD 9, Ms. ___, who was afebrile and not in respiratory 
distress, had CT angio which was positive for multifocal 
bilateral pulmonary emboli.  She was started on a heparin drip 
at 9300 units initial bolus and 2100/hr which was adjusted over 
the next two days from supratherapeutic (PTT>150) to therapeutic 
PTT (67.3) at a rate of 1200 units/hr on POD 10.  She was dosed 
with 2 mg of coumadin from POD 9 through POD 13.  Her heparin 
drip was stopped on POD 11 and switched over to low molecular 
weight heparin (lovenox) at 120 mg BID to ease transition to 
discharge.  Her INR level went from 1.4 (POD 9) to 1.9 (POD 12) 
to 2.3 (POD 13) to 2.9 (POD 14, day of discharge).  On day of 
discharge, patient was instructed to take 1 mg of coumadin to be 
followed by 2 mg daily until she followed up with her PCP within 
three days.

【22】Neuro:
Patient had no major neurological issues during her stay. In the 
ICU, she was on a versed and fentanyl drip for sedation and 
gradually weaned to complement the respiratory ventilator wean 
attempts.  Paralytics were stopped entirely on POD 5.

【23】GI:
Patient was NPO during her ICU stay.  She was started on TPN on 
POD 5.  She was advanced from NPO to sips of clears on POD 6, 
after transfer to the floor.  She tolerated it well and was 
successfully advanced to a regular diet on POD 7. Her TPN was 
stopped on POD 7.  During her stay, her electrolytes were 
carefully monitored and repleted as necessary.

【24】GU:
In the immediate days post-operatively, bladder pressures were 
measured q6 hours to assess for the development of compartment 
syndrome.  Bladder pressures remained in the low twenties and 
transitioned to the high teens during POD 1 and 2 and to the 
mid-teens therafter.

POD 2, in response to Hct in the low twenties compared to 31.8 
pre-op, she was transfused with one unit PRBCs.  On POD 3, 
patient received 2 units of PRBCs.  Hct responded to the low 
thirties.  On discharge, her Hct was 29.9.

remain elevated after POD 7 (14.3).  CXR done on POD 7 showed 
ambiguous opacities in the left lobe consistent with atelectasis 
but unable to rule out pulmonary infection.  This remained 
largely unimproved on POD 9 when her WBC count was 17.1.  She 
was started on antibiotics of vancomycin, levofloxacin and 
cefepime as empiric therapy to cover for nocosomial pneumonia;

【48】8. You were started on coumadin during this hospitalization. 
Some important information regarding coumadin/warfarin therapy:

【49】What is this medicine used for?
This medicine is used to thin the blood so that clots will not 
form.

【50】How does it work?
Warfarin changes the body's clotting system. It thins the blood 
to prevent clots from forming.

【51】What you should contact your healthcare provider ___:
Signs of a life-threatening reaction. These include wheezing; 
chest tightness; fever; itching; bad cough; blue skin color; 
fits; or swelling of face, lips, tongue, or throat, severe 
dizziness or passing out, falls or accidents, especially if you 
hit your head. Talk with healthcare provider even if you feel 
fine, significant change in thinking clearly and logically, 
severe headache, severe back pain, severe belly pain, black, 
tarry, or bloody stools, blood in the urine, nosebleeds, 
coughing up blood, vomiting blood, unusual bruising or bleeding, 
severe menstrual bleedin, or rash.
Call your doctor if you are unable to eat for several days, for 
whatever reason. Also call if you have stomach problems, 
vomiting, or diarrhea that lasts more than 1 day. These problems 
could affect your ___ dosage.

【52】Coumadin (Warfarin) and diet:
Certain foods and beverages can impair the effect of warfarin. 
For this reason, it's important to pay attention to what you eat 
while taking this medication. 
Until recently, doctors advised ___ taking warfarin to avoid 
foods high in vitamin K. This is because large amounts of 
vitamin K can counteract the benefits of warfarin. However, 
recent research shows that rather than eliminating vitamin K 
from your diet, it is more important to be consistent in your 
dietary vitamin K intake.

【53】These foods contain vitamin K:
Fruits and vegetables, such as: Kiwi, Blueberries, Broccoli, 
Cabbage, ___ sprouts, Green onions, Asparagus, Cauliflower, 
Peas, Lettuce, Spinach, Turnip, ___, and mustard greens, 
Parsley, Kale, Endive. Meats, such as: Beef liver, Pork liver. 
Other: ___, Margarine, Canola oil, Soybean oil, Vitamins, 
Soybeans and Cashews.
Limit alcohol. Alcohol can affect your ___ dosage 
but it does not mean you must avoid all alcohol. Serious 
problems can occur with alcohol and ___ when you 
drink more than 2 drinks a day or when you change your usual 
pattern. Binge drinking is not good for you. Be careful on 
special occasions or holidays, and drink only what you usually 
would on any regular day of the week.

【54】Monitoring:
The doctor decides how much ___ you need by 
testing your blood. The test measures how fast your blood is 
clotting and lets the doctor know if your dosage should change. 
If your blood test is too high, you might be at risk for 
bleeding problems. If it is too low, you might be at risk for 
forming clots. Your doctor has decided on a range on the blood 
test that is right for you. The blood test used for monitoring 
is called an INR.
Use of Other medications: 
When ___ is taken with other medicines it can 
change the way other medicines work. Other medicines can also 
change the way ___ works. It is very important to 
talk with your doctor about all of the other medicines that you 
are taking, including over-the-counter medicines, antibiotics, 
vitamins, or herbal products.

【55】DANGER/WARNING SIGNS
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Separation of the incision.
4. Severe nausea and vomiting and lack of bowel movement or gas 
for several days.
5. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
6. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 
. 
.
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.

abnormalities are consistent with a Bell's Palsy in addition to 
a CN V deficit with hearing deficits that may be due to CNXIII 
or branches of the CNVII. The rash was initially vesicular, 
ruptured and now exists in a scaly formation consistent with 
herpes zoster. The cranial nerve deficits include CNV (burning

【16】Brief Hospital Course:
#. Hypoxia:  
Patient admitted with reported home oxygen saturation of 
mid-80s. Home measurement could have been accurate; however, 
patient's oxygen saturation at presentation to ED was at his 
baseline of 94%. Denies any chest pain, dyspnea, fever, chills. 
Patient had a cough for 4 days that was non-productive and was 
resolved at time of admission. This led us to believe that his 
presentation of hypoxia and dyspnea could have been attributed 
to a post-URI bronchitis. He had a leukocytosis of 11.1 upon 
arrival, but no bands and this appears to be his baseline white 
count through the past year. Patient was asymptomatic and had 
his baseline oxygen sat of 94% in ED and upon arrival to the 
floor. Levofloxacin started in ED, but not indicated in this 
patient. We discontinued his levofloxacin immediately after 
arrival to the floor. Overnight the night of admission, the 
patient had an oxygen saturation in the low ___. He required 
supplemental oxygen at 2 L/min. He then experienced some dyspnea 
the morning of discharge; however, this resolved with albuterol 
nebulizer. He was ambulated following combivent administration 
and was able to maintain his oxygen saturation at his baseline 
of 94%. For this reason, patient was discharged on Advair and 
combivent. He had a history of an Advair prescription for ___ 
years with poor compliance.

breath or wheezing. You should also use combivent if your oxygen 
level drops below 94%.

【24】Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was brought emergently to OR on ___ for 
bilateral posterior EVD placement for large bilateral 
intra-ventricular hemorrhage. He was brought to ICU for close 
monitoring. At 0400 on ___ on exam the patient had no corneals 
and developed pupil asymmetry with a nonreactive left pupil. He 
received an additional dose of 50grams of Mannitol. The family 
was at the bedside, a short meeting was held with the family and 
the neurosurgery team regarding the patient's condition and 
prognosis with surgery and without surgery. The family did not 
want any further surgical interventions, they felt that, that is 
what the patient would say if he could. The patient was made 
DNR/DNI. Another family meeting was held with the ICU team 
regarding changing status to CMO. The family requested more time 
in order to give the rest of the family members a chance to say 
goodbye. In the afternoon the  patient was made comfort measures 
only, shortly after he was pronounced dead.
